title: Plugin-Gated Sessions + Click-to-Review
description:
## Problem
The dashboard shows ALL tmux panes running Claude Code, even those without a known session_id. The pane detail view uses pane_id as its primary key, but session_id is the real identifier. There's no way to interactively review a past session transcript.

## Solution
1. Filter dashboard to only show panes registered via the spotter-plugin (known session_id).
2. Change the detail route from `/panes/:pane_id` to `/sessions/:session_id`. The view finds the tmux pane from the session_id (via SessionRegistry for live sessions, or by tmux session name for review sessions).
3. Add click-to-review: clicking a transcript session row launches `claude --resume <id> --fork-session` in a named tmux session (`spotter-review-<short-id>`) and navigates to `/sessions/:session_id` immediately (loading state until tmux is ready).
4. Remove the session dropdown from the detail view — session is determined by the URL.
5. Filter `spotter-review-*` tmux sessions out of dashboard live panes list.

## Acceptance Tests
- GIVEN no plugin-registered panes WHEN dashboard loads THEN no Claude panes shown
- GIVEN a registered pane WHEN dashboard loads THEN pane appears; clicking it navigates to `/sessions/:session_id`
- GIVEN a transcript session row WHEN user clicks Review THEN tmux `spotter-review-*` is launched and user navigates to `/sessions/:session_id`
- GIVEN `/sessions/:session_id` with a live pane WHEN page loads THEN terminal shows live pane output and transcript loads automatically
- GIVEN `/sessions/:session_id` with a review pane not yet ready WHEN page loads THEN loading state shown, terminal connects when ready
- GIVEN review tmux sessions WHEN dashboard loads THEN `spotter-review-*` excluded from live panes

## Rabbit Holes
- Scroll sync in review mode (defer, copy from existing PaneViewLive later)
- Cleaning up stale review tmux sessions
- Race condition: review pane not ready when route loads (handle with loading state)

## No-gos
- No authentication
- No auto-cleanup of review sessions
- No annotation UI changes (keep existing)

---
Rig: spotter. Appetite: reviewed.
Target: `lib/spotter_web/live/`, `lib/spotter/services/`.
Architecture: Phoenix LiveView, Ash, xterm.js, tmux.
Sources: `lib/spotter_web/live/pane_list_live.ex`, `lib/spotter_web/live/pane_view_live.ex`, `lib/spotter/services/tmux.ex`, `lib/spotter/services/session_registry.ex`, `lib/spotter_web/router.ex`.

title: AI-Powered Code Hotspot Scoring
description:
## Problem
The file heatmap ranks files by churn patterns, but cannot assess code quality, complexity, or risk. Users need AI-powered analysis to identify which specific code snippets deserve the most review attention.

## Solution
Use claude_agent_sdk to score code snippets from top heatmap files:
1. Add CodeHotspot schema for scored snippets with rubric factors
2. Integrate claude_agent_sdk for Haiku scoring and Opus review
3. Build scoring pipeline as Oban jobs
4. Display scored hotspots in UI

All computation in Oban jobs. No AI calls in LiveView.

Depends on spotter-et3 (File Change Heatmap) for FileHeatmap data.

Rig: spotter. Appetite: reviewed.

title: Add CodeHotspot Ash resource with rubric scoring schema
description: Create a new CodeHotspot Ash resource in the Transcripts domain. Fields: relative_path, snippet (text excerpt), line_start/line_end, overall_score (0-100 float), rubric factors as a map (complexity, duplication, error_handling, test_coverage, change_risk - each 0-100), model_used (string), scored_at (datetime). Belongs to Project and optionally to FileHeatmap. Upsert on project_id+relative_path+line_start. Include migration, register in domain, add JSON API routes.

title: Implement HotspotScorer service using LangChain
description: Create Spotter.Services.HotspotScorer that uses the langchain dep to call Claude Haiku for scoring code snippets. The service takes a file path + content and returns structured scores (overall + rubric factors). Use a scoring prompt that evaluates: complexity, duplication risk, error handling gaps, test coverage signals, and change risk based on churn. Return {:ok, scores_map} or {:error, reason}. Config for API key via application env.

title: Build ScoreHotspots Oban worker pipeline
description: Create Spotter.Transcripts.Jobs.ScoreHotspots Oban worker. Takes project_id, queries top N FileHeatmap entries by heat_score, reads file content from the project repo, calls HotspotScorer for each file, persists CodeHotspot records. Unique by project_id with 5-minute period. Max attempts: 2. Queue: :default. Handle missing files gracefully (skip). Batch files to avoid rate limits.

title: Add Hotspots LiveView page to display AI-scored results
description: Create SpotterWeb.HotspotsLive at /projects/:project_id/hotspots. Display CodeHotspot entries sorted by overall_score desc. Show file path, overall score badge (color-coded like heatmap), individual rubric factor bars/badges, snippet preview, scored_at timestamp. Add navigation link from heatmap page. Filter by min score. Reuse existing heatmap badge styling patterns.

title: Setup Code Quality Tools (Credo, Dialyxir, mix_audit)
description:
## Problem
Spotter has no automated code quality checks. No static analysis, type checking, or dependency vulnerability scanning.

## Solution
Add three standard Elixir quality tools as dev dependencies:
- **Credo** for static code analysis and style checking
- **Dialyxir** for gradual type checking via Dialyzer
- **mix_audit** for dependency vulnerability scanning

Install via mix igniter.install, generate Credo config, and add a unified mix quality alias.

## Acceptance Tests
- GIVEN tools installed WHEN mix quality runs THEN credo, dialyzer, and deps.audit all execute
- GIVEN .credo.exs exists WHEN mix credo runs THEN project style rules are applied
- GIVEN PLT built WHEN mix dialyzer runs THEN type analysis completes using cache

## Rabbit Holes
- Dialyzer PLT building is slow on first run (2+ minutes) — just document, don't optimize
- Credo defaults may be strict — keep defaults, tune later

## No-gos
- No CI/CD integration yet (separate task)
- No custom Credo checks
- No fixing existing code to satisfy checkers

---
Appetite: small. Target: mix.exs, .credo.exs. Architecture: Igniter for dep installation. Sources: mix.exs.

title: Index Claude Code Transcripts into Ash Domain
description:
## Problem
Spotter needs to review Claude Code sessions, but transcripts are raw JSONL files scattered across ~/.claude/projects/. No way to query by project, time, tool usage, or conversation structure. With worktrees, a single project may span multiple transcript directories.

## Solution
Build Spotter.Transcripts domain with four Ash resources (Project, Session, Message, Subagent) backed by AshSqlite. A runtime config file (priv/spotter.toml) defines tracked projects with regex patterns to match transcript directories (handling worktrees). An Oban job reads the config, scans matching directories, parses JSONL, and upserts into SQLite. Expose via AshJsonApi.

Config example (priv/spotter.toml):
  [projects.spotter]
  pattern = "^-home-marco-projects-spotter"

  [projects.handgemacht]
  pattern = "^-home-marco-projects-handgemacht"

- Projects: defined in config, each matches one or more transcript directories via regex
- Sessions: UUID .jsonl files with slug, timestamps, git branch, cwd
- Messages: individual JSONL lines with type, role, content (stored as map), parent chain
- Subagents: separate JSONL files in {sessionId}/subagents/

## Acceptance Tests
- GIVEN config has a project with pattern WHEN sync runs THEN only matching directories are scanned
- GIVEN a project matches multiple worktree dirs WHEN synced THEN all sessions belong to one Project
- GIVEN a session has subagent files WHEN sync runs THEN subagents created with correct linkage
- GIVEN JSON API running WHEN GET /api/projects THEN configured project list returned
- GIVEN session exists WHEN GET /api/sessions/:id with include=messages THEN session with messages returned

## Rabbit Holes
- Message content varies (string vs array of content blocks) - store as map, don't over-normalize
- Large files (1MB+) - stream JSONL, don't load into memory
- Tool result files in separate .txt - just store reference path for MVP
- Regex pattern complexity - keep simple prefix patterns

## No-gos
- No full-text search indexing
- No real-time sync (scheduled Oban job is fine)
- No transcript modification (read-only)
- No authentication (localhost prototype)
- No LiveView UI yet (JSON API only)

---
Appetite: reviewed. Target: lib/spotter/transcripts/. Architecture: Ash 3.0, AshSqlite, Oban, AshJsonApi. Sources: config/config.exs, lib/spotter/repo.ex, lib/spotter_web/ash_json_api_router.ex.

title: Create Project Config and Domain + Project Resource
description:
Create the runtime config file, a config reader module, the Spotter.Transcripts domain, and Spotter.Transcripts.Project resource.

**Output files:**
- priv/spotter.toml - runtime config defining tracked projects
- lib/spotter/transcripts/config.ex - config reader module
- lib/spotter/transcripts.ex - domain module
- lib/spotter/transcripts/project.ex - resource

**Technical specs:**

Config file (priv/spotter.toml):
  # Transcript source directory
  transcripts_dir = "~/.claude/projects"
  [projects.spotter]
  pattern = "^-home-marco-projects-spotter"

Config reader (lib/spotter/transcripts/config.ex):
- Spotter.Transcripts.Config module
- read!/0 - reads and parses priv/spotter.toml, returns %{transcripts_dir: String.t(), projects: %{name => %{pattern: Regex.t()}}}
- Expand ~ in paths. Compile regex patterns with Regex.compile!/1.
- Add toml hex package to mix.exs dependencies for TOML parsing

Domain (lib/spotter/transcripts.ex): use Ash.Domain, extensions: [AshJsonApi.Domain]. Resources section lists all four resources.

Project resource attributes:

- name (string, required) - config key like "spotter"
- pattern (string, required) - regex pattern string like "^-home-marco-projects-spotter"

Identity: unique_name on name
Relationships: has_many :sessions, Spotter.Transcripts.Session
Data layer: AshSqlite.DataLayer, table "projects", repo Spotter.Repo
Actions: :create, :read (get + list), :update, :destroy

**Source references:** lib/spotter/repo.ex, config/config.exs (Spark formatter section_order)

**Edge cases:**

Relationships: belongs_to :project, has_many :messages, has_many :subagents

**Source references:** lib/spotter/transcripts/project.ex, example JSONL fields: sessionId, slug, cwd, gitBranch, version, timestamp

**Edge cases:** Some sessions lack slug. Timestamps are ISO 8601 strings. message_count computed during ingestion. transcript_dir tracks which worktree directory the session came from.

title: Build JSONL Parser Module
description:
Create Spotter.Transcripts.JsonlParser to parse .jsonl transcript files.

**Output files:** lib/spotter/transcripts/jsonl_parser.ex

**Technical specs:**

Public functions:
- parse_session_file(path) -> {:ok, %{session_id, slug, cwd, git_branch, version, schema_version, started_at, ended_at, messages}} or {:error, reason}
- parse_subagent_file(path) -> same structure plus agent_id
- detect_schema_version(first_messages) -> integer (1 for current format, bump when format changes)

Implementation:
- Use File.stream!/1 for line-by-line reading (memory-safe for large files)
- Jason.decode/1 each line, skip malformed lines with Logger warning
- Extract session metadata from first messages with sessionId, slug, etc.
- Detect schema version from message structure (presence/absence of fields, content format)
- Normalize content per schema version: v1 uses message["message"]["content"] || message["content"]
- Parse timestamps with DateTime.from_iso8601/1
- Return plain maps with schema_version included - Oban job calls Ash actions to persist

Schema version detection: Currently only v1 exists. When Claude Code changes format, add a new version detector clause. Version is determined by inspecting the first few messages for structural differences (e.g. new fields, changed content format).

**Source references:** Example files at ~/.claude/projects/-home-marco-projects-spotter/*.jsonl

**Edge cases:** Large files must stream. Some lines have invalid JSON. Content can be string or array. Some messages lack timestamps.

**Definition of Done:**
- All requirements implemented
- Tests exist and pass

title: Build Transcript Sync Oban Job
description:
Create Spotter.Transcripts.Jobs.SyncTranscripts Oban worker to scan and ingest transcripts based on config.

**Output files:** lib/spotter/transcripts/jobs/sync_transcripts.ex

**Technical specs:**

use Oban.Worker, queue: :default, max_attempts: 3

Functions:
- sync_all/0 - reads Spotter.Transcripts.Config, for each configured project: lists dirs in transcripts_dir matching the project's regex pattern, enqueues one job per project
- perform(%Oban.Job{args: %{"project_name" => name, "pattern" => pattern}}):
  1. Upsert project via Ash action (match on name identity)
  2. List transcript dirs matching regex in ~/.claude/projects/
  3. For each matching dir, list .jsonl files
  4. For each file: parse with JsonlParser, upsert session (with transcript_dir), bulk create messages
  5. Scan {session_id}/subagents/ dirs, parse subagent files, upsert subagents + messages

Use Ash.bulk_create! for messages (batch 500). Skip already-synced sessions (check existence by session_id).

**Source references:** lib/spotter/transcripts/config.ex, lib/spotter/transcripts/jsonl_parser.ex, all resource files, config/config.exs (Oban queues)

**Edge cases:** Empty dirs - skip. Duplicate runs - upsert handles it. Large sessions - batch inserts. Missing subagent dirs - check existence.

**Definition of Done:**
- All requirements implemented
- Tests exist and pass

title: Harden tmux pane parsing for malformed integer fields
description:
## Objective
Make tmux pane parsing resilient to malformed or partial `list-panes -F` output so `list_panes/0` never crashes on bad integer fields.

## Output Files
- `lib/spotter/services/tmux.ex`
- `test/spotter/services/tmux_test.exs`

## Required Implementation
1. In `lib/spotter/services/tmux.ex`, refactor `parse_pane_line/1` to avoid direct `String.to_integer/1` for these fields:
   - `window_index`
   - `pane_index`
   - `pane_width`
   - `pane_height`
2. Add a private safe integer helper (for example `parse_int_or_default/2`) that:
   - accepts missing/empty/non-numeric values,
   - returns parsed integer only when the entire value is a valid integer,
   - defaults to `0` for malformed or missing input.
3. Apply this helper to all four numeric fields above. For malformed/missing input, all four must resolve to `0` (including width/height).

## Test Requirements
1. Add `test/spotter/services/tmux_test.exs` with unit coverage for `list_panes/0`.
2. Use a temp-path fake `tmux` executable (or equivalent deterministic command injection strategy) that returns controlled `list-panes` output lines, including malformed numeric tokens.
3. Include at least these scenarios:
   - non-integer tokens (`abc`, `--`, empty token) in each numeric position,
   - partial row with missing trailing fields,
   - mixed valid + malformed rows in one output.
4. Assertions:
   - `Spotter.Services.Tmux.list_panes/0` returns `{:ok, panes}` and does not raise,
   - malformed numeric fields resolve to `0`,
   - valid numeric fields still parse correctly.

## Acceptance Criteria
- Malformed/partial `tmux list-panes -F` lines no longer raise `FunctionClauseError`/`ArgumentError` through integer conversion.
- `list_panes/0` is deterministic and returns pane maps with safe defaults.

title: Harden runtime env parsing for repo pool size and OTEL exporter
description:
## Objective
Harden runtime environment parsing so invalid `POOL_SIZE` or `OTEL_EXPORTER` values cannot crash production boot.

## Output Files
- `config/runtime.exs`
- `lib/spotter/config/env_parser.ex` (new helper module)

title: Limit transcript sync to 20 most recent sessions per project
description:
## Problem

The transcript sync job (`lib/spotter/transcripts/jobs/sync_transcripts.ex`) processes ALL `.jsonl` files found in a project directory. For projects with hundreds or thousands of Claude Code sessions, this means:

- Full sync takes minutes or longer
- User waits for UI feedback after clicking "Sync"
- Database performs thousands of upserts (sessions, messages, tool calls, subagents)
- Older sessions dominate the work, delaying recent session availability

The bottleneck is `sync_directory/2` (line 108-120), which wildcards ALL files and processes each sequentially without limit.

## Solution

Sort transcript files by modification time descending and sync only the 20 most recent per directory. Add a `@max_sessions_per_sync 20` module attribute. Log when the limit is applied.

## Acceptance Tests

- GIVEN a directory with 50 JSONL files WHEN sync runs THEN only the 20 most recently modified files are processed
- GIVEN files with varying mtimes WHEN sync runs THEN the most recent 20 are selected
- GIVEN a directory with 5 JSONL files WHEN sync runs THEN all 5 are processed (no artificial padding)
- GIVEN sync completes with limit applied WHEN logger output is reviewed THEN it indicates how many of total sessions were synced

## Rabbit Holes

- Do NOT add per-project configuration for the limit — keep it hardcoded as `@max_sessions_per_sync 20`
- Do NOT change broadcast messages or UI components
- Do NOT refactor sync job architecture

## No-gos

- Do NOT remove or alter existing session data in the database
- Do NOT change the sync_all flow or Oban job enqueueing
- Do NOT modify the JSONL parser or session upsert logic

---
Appetite: automated. Target: `lib/spotter/transcripts/jobs/`. Sources: `lib/spotter/transcripts/jobs/sync_transcripts.ex`.

title: Limit sync_directory to 20 most recent JSONL files
description:
Modify `sync_directory/2` in `lib/spotter/transcripts/jobs/sync_transcripts.ex` to sort JSONL files by modification time (descending) and process only the 20 most recent. This bounds sync time regardless of how many sessions exist on disk.

## Output files

- Modify: `lib/spotter/transcripts/jobs/sync_transcripts.ex`

## Technical specs

1. Add module attribute after `@batch_size 500` (line 15):
   ```elixir
   @max_sessions_per_sync 20
   ```

2. Replace `sync_directory/2` (lines 108-120) with:
   ```elixir
   defp sync_directory(project, dir) do
     all_files =
       dir
       |> Path.join("*.jsonl")
       |> Path.wildcard()

     files =
       all_files
       |> Enum.sort_by(fn path -> File.stat!(path, time: :posix).mtime end, :desc)
       |> Enum.take(@max_sessions_per_sync)

     if length(all_files) > @max_sessions_per_sync do
       Logger.info(
         "Syncing #{length(files)} of #{length(all_files)} sessions in #{Path.basename(dir)} (limited to #{@max_sessions_per_sync} most recent)"
       )
     end

     Enum.each(files, fn file ->
       sync_session_file(project, dir, file)
     end)

     length(files)
   end
   ```

Key details:
- `File.stat!/2` with `time: :posix` returns integer mtime (seconds since epoch), efficient for sorting
- Single wildcard pass, then sort + take — no double globbing
- Log message only appears when limit is actually applied
- Return value is the count of files actually synced (not total found)

## Source references

- `lib/spotter/transcripts/jobs/sync_transcripts.ex` — current implementation (lines 15, 108-120)

## Edge cases

- Directories with fewer than 20 files: `Enum.take/2` returns all elements, no issue
- Files with identical mtimes: order among them is non-deterministic but acceptable
- Symlinked files: `File.stat!/2` follows symlinks by default, which is correct

## Definition of Done

- [ ] All requirements in the task description are implemented
- [ ] `mix test` passes
- [ ] No new Credo warnings (`mix credo --strict`)
- [ ] Manual verification: trigger sync with 20+ sessions, confirm log output and bounded processing

title: Capture commit hashes in fast hook path (minimal payload)
description:
## Output Files

## Implement
Update Bash hook flow to keep latency low and send minimal commit events.

1. PreToolUse Bash branch
- Continue baseline file tracking for changed files behavior.
- Add HEAD baseline file: `/tmp/spotter-git-head-${TOOL_USE_ID}.txt`
  - value from `git rev-parse HEAD` or empty string if unavailable.

2. PostToolUse Bash branch
- Read baseline head and current `git rev-parse HEAD`.
- If either unavailable, still POST minimal event with available values.
- Compute commit range only (no per-commit `git show`):
  - `git rev-list --reverse ${BASE_HEAD}..${HEAD}` when both exist and differ.
- Cap hashes to first 50 entries.
- Build payload:
  - `session_id`
  - `tool_use_id`
  - `git_branch` (`git branch --show-current` best-effort)
  - `base_head`
  - `head`
  - `new_commit_hashes` (array)
  - `captured_at` (ISO8601 UTC)
- POST to `/api/hooks/commit-event`.

3. Performance rules
- Never call `git show` or `git patch-id` inside hook scripts.
- cURL timeouts:
  - `--connect-timeout 0.1`
  - `--max-time 0.3`
- Preserve silent-fail semantics (`trap 'exit 0' ERR`).

4. Hook matcher
- Keep matcher scoped to `Write|Edit|Bash` only.
- Do not add new hook event types in this task.

## Acceptance
- Bash tool that creates commits sends one minimal commit-event POST.
- Hooks remain non-blocking and fast by construction.
- Existing file snapshot behavior remains functional.

description:
## Output Files

- `test/spotter/transcripts/jobs/enrich_commits_test.exs` (new)

## Implement
Move expensive git work to backend async processing.

1. Enrichment worker
- Input args include commit hashes and optional branch/session context.
- For each hash, gather metadata via git commands in worker context:
  - parents, subject, body, author info, authored/committed timestamps
  - changed files list
  - stable patch id via `git show <hash> | git patch-id --stable`
- Update Commit rows with enriched fields.
- Safe on missing commits / detached histories: skip and continue.

2. Linker service
- After enrichment, compute inferred links with evidence.
- Rules and fixed confidence:
  - `descendant_of_observed`: `0.90`
  - `patch_match`: `0.85`
  - `file_overlap`: `0.60` when:
    - Jaccard overlap >= `0.70`
    - time delta <= `360` minutes
- Persist only `confidence >= 0.60`.
- Never replace an existing link for same `(session, commit)` if existing confidence is higher.

3. Triggering
- `commit_event/2` enqueues enrichment worker after ingest.
- Worker invokes linker once metadata is available.

## Acceptance
- Metadata fields are eventually populated for ingested hashes.
- Inferred links are created with correct confidence and evidence keys.
- Failures in enrichment do not break API ingest path.

- `lib/spotter/transcripts/jobs/sync_transcripts.ex`

title: Co-Change Group Analysis
description:
## Goal
Deliver project-level co-change analysis that shows which files and directories repeatedly change together, so reviewers can quickly spot coupling and blast radius.

## Target area
- `lib/spotter/services/`
- `lib/spotter/transcripts/`
- `lib/spotter/transcripts/jobs/`
- `lib/spotter_web/live/`
- `lib/spotter_web/controllers/`
- `test/spotter/services/`
- `test/spotter/transcripts/jobs/`
- `test/spotter_web/live/`

## Architecture constraints
- Keep the set-intersection algorithm in a pure-function service module with no Ash/Oban/LiveView dependencies.
- Follow TDD for the algorithm: write/lock tests before implementation.
- Run heavy computation in Oban workers only; never in LiveView render/event paths.
- Use the same ingestion trigger pattern as heatmap (`HooksController` + `SyncTranscripts`) and the same git-history source pattern (`GitLogReader` from project `cwd`).
- Persist computed co-change groups in Ash resources for query/render (no ad-hoc in-memory cache).

## Source references
- `lib/spotter/services/heatmap_calculator.ex`
- `lib/spotter/services/git_log_reader.ex`
- `lib/spotter/transcripts/file_heatmap.ex`
- `lib/spotter/transcripts/jobs/compute_heatmap.ex`
- `lib/spotter/transcripts/jobs/sync_transcripts.ex`
- `lib/spotter_web/controllers/hooks_controller.ex`
- `lib/spotter_web/live/heatmap_live.ex`
- `lib/spotter_web/live/pane_list_live.ex`

## Solution outline
1. Add a persistence resource for computed co-change groups (file and directory scope).
2. Implement and test a pure set-intersection algorithm that returns minimal generating groups with frequency and recency.
3. Add an Oban compute job/service that reads recent git commits, computes groups, and upserts/deletes rows.
4. Add a project LiveView list that shows each file/directory with its max co-change frequency and all groups it belongs to.

## Acceptance tests
GIVEN recent commits with changed file sets `{A,B,C}`, `{A,B}`, `{B,C}`, `{B,C,D}`
WHEN co-change computation runs
THEN file-level groups include `{A,B}` with frequency 2 and `{B,C}` with frequency 3

GIVEN the same commits mapped to directories
WHEN directory-level computation runs
THEN directory groups are persisted with `scope = :directory` and deterministic keys

GIVEN new commit/snapshot ingest events
WHEN hooks or transcript sync complete
THEN `ComputeCoChange` is enqueued once per project (Oban unique on project_id)

GIVEN co-change data exists for a project
WHEN visiting `/projects/:project_id/co-change`
THEN rows are sorted by max group frequency desc, with per-row group membership visible for file and directory scopes

## Rabbit Holes
- Do not add AI scoring, snippet generation, or annotation coupling here.
- Do not run git operations from hook scripts; backend workers only.
- Do not introduce graph DB dependencies for V1; relational persistence only.

## No-gos
- No authentication work.
- No backwards-compatibility shims (greenfield).
- No Oban Pro-only features.
close_reason: All 4 subtasks complete: persistence schema, TDD algorithm, Oban worker with triggers, and LiveView

title: Implement pure co-change intersection algorithm (TDD)
description:
Implement the pure set-intersection algorithm module for co-change groups. Write tests first.

## Output files
- `test/spotter/services/co_change_intersections_test.exs` (new; write first)
- `lib/spotter/services/co_change_intersections.ex` (new)

## Technical specs

### Public API
Create `Spotter.Services.CoChangeIntersections` with:
- `compute(commits, scope: :file | :directory)`

Input shape:
- `commits` is a list of maps with keys `:hash`, `:timestamp`, `:files`
- `:files` is a list of changed file paths from git history

Return shape:
- list of maps: `%{group_key: String.t(), members: [String.t()], frequency_30d: pos_integer(), last_seen_at: DateTime.t()}`

### Algorithm
1. Normalize each commit to a unique member set:
   - `scope: :file` => member = file path
   - `scope: :directory` => member = `Path.dirname(file_path)` (`"."` for repo-root files)
2. For file scope, drop binary files using the same extension list currently used by `HeatmapCalculator`.
3. Drop commits whose normalized set has fewer than 2 members.
4. Build candidates from pairwise intersections of commit sets.
5. Keep only intersections with size >= 2; dedupe by set equality.
6. Compute support frequency for each candidate as count of commits where candidate is subset of commit set.
7. Minimal-generator pruning: drop candidate `G` when there exists candidate `H` such that `H` is a strict subset of `G` and `frequency(H) == frequency(G)`.
8. `group_key = members |> Enum.sort() |> Enum.join("|")`.
9. `last_seen_at` = max timestamp among supporting commits.
10. Deterministic output sort: `frequency_30d desc`, `length(members) desc`, `group_key asc`.

## Test cases (must exist)
- Example fixture `{A,B,C}`, `{A,B}`, `{B,C}`, `{B,C,D}` => groups `{A,B}` frequency 2 and `{B,C}` frequency 3.
- Duplicate file entries inside one commit are deduplicated.
- Single-file commits do not produce groups.
- Directory scope maps `mix.exs` to `"."` and nested files to their full dirname.
- Binary files are excluded from file-scope grouping.
- Output ordering is deterministic.

## Source references
- `lib/spotter/services/heatmap_calculator.ex`
- `lib/spotter/services/git_log_reader.ex`

## Definition of Done
- Algorithm module has no Ash/Oban dependencies.
- Tests fully cover algorithm and pass.
close_reason: Pure algorithm implemented with TDD, 13 tests passing, no Ash/Oban deps

title: Compute and persist co-change groups via Oban
description:
Compute and persist co-change groups in an Oban worker using recent git history, then wire ingest triggers.

## Technical specs

### CoChangeCalculator service
Create `Spotter.Services.CoChangeCalculator.compute(project_id, opts \\ [])`.
Options:
- `:window_days` default `30`
- `:reference_date` default `DateTime.utc_now/0`

Flow:
1. Resolve repo path from most recent project session with non-nil `cwd` (same pattern as heatmap calculator).
2. Read commits via `GitLogReader.changed_files_by_commit(repo_path, since_days: window_days)`.
3. Compute file groups with `CoChangeIntersections.compute(commits, scope: :file)`.
4. Compute directory groups with `CoChangeIntersections.compute(commits, scope: :directory)`.
5. Upsert `CoChangeGroup` rows for both scopes.
6. Delete stale rows not present in current computation per `project_id + scope`.

Failure handling:
- Missing/inaccessible repo path: log warning and return `:ok` without crashing.
- Git command errors: return `:ok` and keep existing rows intact.

### Oban worker
Create `Spotter.Transcripts.Jobs.ComputeCoChange`:
- `queue: :default`
- `max_attempts: 3`
- `unique: [keys: [:project_id], period: 30]`
- `perform/1` delegates to `CoChangeCalculator.compute(project_id)`

### Enqueue triggers
Enqueue `ComputeCoChange` anywhere `ComputeHeatmap` is currently enqueued for project ingest updates:
- `HooksController.commit_event/2`
- `HooksController.file_snapshot/2`
- `SyncTranscripts.perform/1` (once per synced project)

- `lib/spotter/transcripts/jobs/compute_heatmap.ex`
- `lib/spotter_web/controllers/hooks_controller.ex`
- `lib/spotter/transcripts/jobs/sync_transcripts.ex`

## Edge cases
- No commits in window => clear existing co-change rows for project and keep job successful.
- Commits with empty `files` list are ignored.

- Worker runs end-to-end without raising for empty/missing repo scenarios.
- Tests validate file + directory persistence, stale cleanup, and trigger wiring behavior.

title: End-to-end OpenTelemetry tracing (plugin -> Phoenix -> Ash -> LiveView)
description:
## Goal
Implement end-to-end OpenTelemetry tracing for Spotter from Claude plugin hook execution through Phoenix API ingress, Ash domain actions, LiveView interactions, and terminal channel events.

## Target Area
- `spotter-plugin/scripts/`
- `lib/spotter/telemetry/`
- `lib/spotter/application.ex`
- `lib/spotter_web/endpoint.ex`
- `lib/spotter_web/controllers/`
- `lib/spotter_web/channels/`
- `config/`
- `test/spotter_web/controllers/`
- `test/spotter_web/live/`
- `README.md`

## Architecture Constraints
- Stack is Elixir + Phoenix + Ash + Bandit; use `opentelemetry_bandit`, `opentelemetry_phoenix`, and `opentelemetry_ash`.
- Do not use `ash_opentelemetry`; use `opentelemetry_ash` and set `config :ash, :tracer, [OpentelemetryAsh]`.
- Default local mode is console exporter (`otel_exporter_stdout`) so tracing works without a collector.
- Hook scripts must preserve current silent-fail semantics and timeout budgets (never block Claude execution).
- Missing/invalid `traceparent` must never cause 4xx/5xx responses.
- Tracing setup failure must degrade gracefully (log + continue app startup).
- No schema migrations and no API route changes.

## Source References
- `spotter-plugin/scripts/notify-session.sh`
- `spotter-plugin/scripts/tool-call-capture.sh`
- `spotter-plugin/scripts/post-tool-capture.sh`
- `lib/spotter/application.ex`
- `lib/spotter_web/endpoint.ex`
- `lib/spotter_web/controllers/session_hook_controller.ex`

- `config/config.exs`
- `config/dev.exs`

- `config/runtime.exs`
- https://hexdocs.pm/opentelemetry_ash/getting-started-with-opentelemetry-ash.html
- https://hexdocs.pm/opentelemetry_phoenix/OpentelemetryPhoenix.html
- https://hexdocs.pm/opentelemetry_bandit/OpentelemetryBandit.html
- https://hexdocs.pm/phoenix_live_view/telemetry.html
- https://www.w3.org/TR/trace-context/

## Success Criteria
- Every plugin hook POST can emit `traceparent` and backend continues the trace when header is valid.
- Hook API spans include outcome/error attributes and return a trace id header for correlation.
- Ash action spans are emitted with reduced noise (`[:custom, :action, :flow]`).
- LiveView user interactions (`handle_event`) and TerminalChannel lifecycle are traced on server side.
- Existing behavior/latency of hook endpoints remains functionally unchanged.

Propagate W3C trace context from plugin hooks to backend hook endpoints.

1. Create shared shell helper `spotter-plugin/scripts/lib/trace_context.sh` with:
- `spotter_rand_hex <bytes>`: returns lowercase hex, prefers `openssl rand -hex`, fallback to `/proc/sys/kernel/random/uuid` conversion.
- `spotter_generate_traceparent`: emits `00-<32 hex trace_id>-<16 hex span_id>-01`.
- If ids cannot be generated, return empty string (do not fail script).

2. Update all outbound hook POST scripts (`notify-session.sh`, `tool-call-capture.sh`, `post-tool-capture.sh`):
- Source helper file with safe guard (`[ -f ... ] && . ...`).
- Build `TRACEPARENT="$(spotter_generate_traceparent)"`.
- Add request headers:
  - `traceparent: ${TRACEPARENT}` only when non-empty
  - `x-spotter-hook-event: <hook event name>`
  - `x-spotter-hook-script: <script basename>`
- Hook event value rules:
  - `notify-session.sh`: `SessionStart`
  - `tool-call-capture.sh`: `.hook_event_name` from stdin, fallback `PostToolUse`
  - `post-tool-capture.sh`: `.hook_event_name` from stdin, fallback `PostToolUse`

3. Preserve non-blocking hook contract:
- Keep existing `trap 'exit 0' ERR` behavior where already present.
- Keep current `curl` timeout values unchanged.
- Never fail the hook because trace header generation failed.

## Technical Requirements
- Do not change existing JSON payload schemas.
- Do not print trace or payload content to stdout/stderr in normal flow.
- Keep script behavior identical when tracing is unavailable.

## Edge Cases
- `openssl` unavailable.
- Random source unavailable.
- Stdin lacks `hook_event_name`.
- `TRACEPARENT` empty string.

## Definition of Done
- Every hook POST attempts to include trace context headers.
- Scripts still succeed silently when trace context cannot be generated.
- Existing hook API payloads remain backward-compatible.

title: Review session launches claude --resume without the session's working directory
description:
## Problem

When clicking "Review" on a session in Spotter, the xterm.js terminal launches `claude --resume <session_id> --fork-session` via tmux, but the tmux session starts from Spotter's server CWD instead of the original session's working directory. Claude Code then fails with "No conversation found with session ID: ..." because it derives the project directory from the CWD.

Example: session `25879125-2c29-42fa-9893-8053c942a232` was created in `/home/marco/projects/spotter-worktrees/spotter-obz` (now deleted), so Claude Code stored it in `~/.claude/projects/-home-marco-projects-spotter-worktrees-spotter-obz/`. Without the correct CWD, Claude Code looks in the wrong project directory.

**Extra complication**: For worktree sessions, the original CWD may no longer exist after the worktree is deleted post-merge.

## Root Cause

`Tmux.launch_review_session/1` (`lib/spotter/services/tmux.ex:121`) calls:
```
tmux new-session -d -s name claude --resume session_id --fork-session
```
without the `-c <cwd>` flag. The session's `cwd` IS stored in the database but is never looked up or passed to tmux.

## Acceptance Tests

- GIVEN a synced session from an existing directory WHEN clicking "Review" THEN the tmux session starts in the session's CWD and claude --resume succeeds
- GIVEN a synced session from a deleted worktree WHEN clicking "Review" THEN the tmux session starts in the best available fallback directory and claude --resume succeeds (or shows a clear error if no viable directory exists)
- GIVEN a session with nil cwd WHEN clicking "Review" THEN current behavior is preserved (no -c flag)

## Rabbit Holes

- Claude Code has no `--cwd` or `--project-dir` flag. It derives the project context entirely from the actual CWD. For deleted worktrees, we must `mkdir -p` the original path so tmux can `-c` into it.

## No-gos

- Not modifying Claude Code itself
- Not adding worktree recreation logic beyond simple `mkdir -p` if needed

## Files Involved

- `lib/spotter/services/tmux.ex` — `launch_review_session/1` (line 121)
- `lib/spotter_web/live/pane_list_live.ex` — `handle_event("review_session", ...)` (line 34)
- `lib/spotter/transcripts/session.ex` — Session resource with `cwd` attribute
close_reason: Fixed by passing session cwd to tmux launch and handling deleted worktrees with mkdir -p

title: Pass session cwd to tmux and handle deleted worktrees
description:
Fix `launch_review_session` to start the tmux session in the correct working directory, with graceful handling for deleted worktrees.

## Output files
- `lib/spotter/services/tmux.ex` (modify)
- `lib/spotter_web/live/pane_list_live.ex` (modify)

## Implementation

### Step 1: Update `launch_review_session/1` to accept optional cwd

In `lib/spotter/services/tmux.ex`, change the function signature and add `-c` to the tmux args:

```elixir
def launch_review_session(session_id, opts \\ []) do
  short_id = String.slice(session_id, 0, 8)
  name = "spotter-review-#{short_id}"
  cwd = resolve_cwd(Keyword.get(opts, :cwd))

  base_args = ["new-session", "-d", "-s", name]
  cwd_args = if cwd, do: ["-c", cwd], else: []
  cmd_args = ["claude", "--resume", session_id, "--fork-session"]

  case System.cmd("tmux", base_args ++ cwd_args ++ cmd_args, stderr_to_stdout: true) do
    {_, 0} -> {:ok, name}
    {output, _} -> {:error, String.trim(output)}
  end
rescue
  e in ErlangError -> {:error, Exception.message(e)}
end

# If directory exists, use it. If not, create it (for deleted worktrees).
# Returns nil if cwd is nil.
defp resolve_cwd(nil), do: nil
defp resolve_cwd(cwd) do
  if File.dir?(cwd) do
    cwd
  else
    # Deleted worktree — recreate the directory so Claude Code
    # can derive the correct project path from CWD.
    File.mkdir_p!(cwd)
    cwd
  end
end
```

Claude Code has no `--cwd` flag — it derives the project from the actual CWD. For deleted worktrees, `mkdir -p` recreates the path so tmux can start there and Claude Code finds its `~/.claude/projects/<dir>/` data.

### Step 2: Look up session cwd in the event handler

In `lib/spotter_web/live/pane_list_live.ex`, modify the `review_session` event handler:

```elixir
def handle_event("review_session", %{"session-id" => session_id}, socket) do
  cwd = lookup_session_cwd(session_id)
  Task.start(fn -> Tmux.launch_review_session(session_id, cwd: cwd) end)
  {:noreply, push_navigate(socket, to: "/sessions/#{session_id}")}
end

defp lookup_session_cwd(session_id) do
  case Session |> Ash.Query.filter(session_id == ^session_id) |> Ash.read_one() do
    {:ok, %Session{cwd: cwd}} when is_binary(cwd) -> cwd
    _ -> nil
  end
end
```

Add `alias Spotter.Transcripts.Session` and `require Ash.Query` to the module if not already present.

## Source references
- `lib/spotter/services/tmux.ex:116-135` — current `launch_review_session/1`
- `lib/spotter_web/live/pane_list_live.ex:34-37` — current event handler
- `lib/spotter/transcripts/session.ex:88` — `cwd` attribute on Session resource

## Edge cases
- Session not in DB (cwd is nil): no `-c` flag, same as current behavior
- Session cwd is nil: no `-c` flag, same as current behavior
- Deleted worktree: `mkdir -p` recreates the path so Claude Code finds its project directory
- `mkdir -p` fails (permissions): rescue catches it, falls back to no `-c` flag

## Architecture constraints
- Keep `Tmux` module free of direct Ash/DB dependencies — the lookup stays in the LiveView
- No new dependencies or migrations needed

## Definition of Done
- All requirements in the task description are implemented.
- Verified that `claude --resume` works from a `mkdir -p`'d worktree path.
- Clicking "Review" on a session opens Claude Code in the correct working directory.
- Clicking "Review" on a session from a deleted worktree still works (via chosen fallback strategy).
- Sessions with missing/nil cwd still launch (without `-c` flag, same as today).
- For unrelated changes, new beads with label:refinement were created.
close_reason: Implemented cwd passthrough to tmux and directory resolution for deleted worktrees

title: Refactor PaneListLive with AshComputer reactive state
description:
## Problem

PaneListLive (lib/spotter_web/live/pane_list_live.ex, 523 LOC) manages complex, fragmented state across multiple assigns:
- 4 pagination fields per project (visible_cursor, visible_has_more, hidden_cursor, hidden_has_more)
- Separate load phases for sessions vs tool call stats
- 9 handle_event callbacks with implicit dependency chains between state updates
- Manual pagination state tracking via pagination_keys/1 helper to avoid hardcoding field names
- Ash.read! calls without error handling (crashes LiveView on failures)

When selected_project_id changes, sessions and stats must be manually reloaded. There is no automatic propagation.

## Solution

Introduce ash_computer (reactive computation DSL) to replace scattered state management with three declarative computers defined inline in PaneListLive:

1. **ProjectFilter computer** - Manages project list and selected project filter. When selected_project_id changes, dependent computers recompute automatically.
2. **SessionPagination computer** - Manages cursor-based pagination for visible/hidden sessions per project. Replaces 4+ pagination assigns per project with reactive vals.
3. **ToolCallStats computer** - Loads error counts per session reactively when session_ids change. Replaces separate load_tool_call_stats phase.

All Ash.read calls in computer vals wrapped in try/catch to return nil/[] on error instead of crashing.

## Acceptance Tests

- GIVEN PaneListLive mounts WHEN ash_computer is integrated THEN all three computers initialize via mount_computers(socket) and projects display correctly
- GIVEN a user clicks a project filter chip WHEN the filter_project event fires THEN SessionPagination recomputes with sessions for only that project
- GIVEN sessions are loaded WHEN user clicks Load More THEN pagination cursor updates and new sessions append without full page reload
- GIVEN sessions are loaded WHEN ToolCallStats computer observes session_ids THEN error counts display correctly per session (total and failed)
- GIVEN an Ash.read query fails WHEN a computer val recomputes THEN the val returns nil/[] and the template renders empty state (no LiveView crash)
- GIVEN the refactored PaneListLive WHEN user navigates to Review THEN SessionLive loads correctly (no regression)

## Rabbit Holes

- Pagination state for visible vs hidden sessions per project may require careful input modeling (compound inputs or separate computers). Start with a single SessionPagination computer with visibility_type input.
- ash_computer event macro may conflict with existing Phoenix helpers. Test compilation early.
- Compute function dependency detection relies on pattern matching in fn signatures. Use explicit depends_on if needed.

## No-gos

- No changes to PaneViewLive, SessionLive, or DebugTerminalLive in this epic
- No database schema changes or migrations
- No changes to SyncTranscripts job or PubSub sync handlers
- No changes to routes or URL structure

---
Rig: spotter. Appetite: supervised.
Target: lib/spotter_web/live/pane_list_live.ex.
Architecture: Ash, Phoenix LiveView, ash_computer (new dependency).
Sources: lib/spotter_web/live/pane_list_live.ex, /tmp/ash_computer_research/ash_computer/README.md.

title: Define ProjectFilter computer inline in PaneListLive
description:
Define a ProjectFilter computer inline in PaneListLive to manage the project list and selected project filter state.

## What and Why

Currently, PaneListLive loads projects via a private `load_projects/1` function that calls `Ash.read\!` on `Spotter.Transcripts.Project` and maps over results to attach pagination state. The selected_project_id is tracked as a plain assign. By modeling this as an ash_computer computer, project loading becomes a reactive val that can be recomputed on demand, and the filter_project event becomes type-safe.

## Output files

- `lib/spotter_web/live/pane_list_live.ex` — Add `use AshComputer.LiveView`, define `computer :project_filter` block, update mount to call `mount_computers(socket)`, update template to use `event(:project_filter, :filter_project)`

## Technical specs

Define inline in PaneListLive:

```elixir
use AshComputer.LiveView

computer :project_filter do
  input :selected_project_id do
    initial nil
    description "Currently selected project ID for filtering, nil means all"
  end

  val :projects do
    description "All projects loaded from database"
    compute fn _inputs ->
      try do
        Spotter.Transcripts.Project |> Ash.read\!()
      rescue
        _ -> []
      end
    end
    depends_on []
  end

  event :filter_project do
    handle fn _values, %{"project-id" => "all"} ->
      %{selected_project_id: nil}
    end
  end

  event :select_project do
    handle fn _values, %{"project-id" => project_id} ->
      %{selected_project_id: project_id}
    end
  end
end
```

In mount, replace the initial assigns with:
```elixir
socket
|> assign(panes: [], claude_panes: [], loading: true)
|> assign(sync_status: %{}, sync_stats: %{})
|> assign(hidden_expanded: %{})
|> mount_computers()
|> load_panes()
```

Update template filter buttons to use `event(:project_filter, :filter_project)` or `event(:project_filter, :select_project)`.

Template assigns become `@project_filter_selected_project_id` and `@project_filter_projects`.

## Component usage

- `use AshComputer.LiveView` — Provides mount_computers/1, event/2, update_computer_inputs/3
- `require Ash.Query` — Already present

## Source references

- `lib/spotter_web/live/pane_list_live.ex` lines 1-27 (mount), lines 57-63 (filter_project handlers), lines 128-149 (load_projects)
- ash_computer LiveView integration: README section "LiveView Integration" and "Custom Event Handlers"

## Edge cases

- The projects val has no inputs (it always loads all projects). Use `depends_on []` to make dependency explicit.
- Error handling: Wrap Ash.read\! in try/rescue to return [] on error. Template already handles empty projects list.
- The filter_project event currently has two clauses ("all" and specific ID). May need two events or handle in a single event with pattern matching.

## Architecture constraints

- Keep `load_panes/1` as a regular private function (not a computer) — it depends on tmux system calls, not reactive state
- Keep PubSub subscription and sync handlers untouched
- Template uses inline styles (existing pattern, don't change)

title: Define SessionPagination computer for cursor-based pagination
description:
Define a SessionPagination computer inline in PaneListLive to replace the fragmented pagination state (4 fields per project: visible_cursor, visible_has_more, hidden_cursor, hidden_has_more).

## What and Why

PaneListLive currently tracks pagination state for each project by merging 4 extra map keys into each project struct (visible_cursor, visible_has_more, hidden_cursor, hidden_has_more). The `pagination_keys/1` helper exists solely to avoid hardcoding these field names. The `append_session_page/3` and `do_append_session_page/4` functions manually update these fields on the correct project in the list. This scattered state is hard to follow and error-prone.

An ash_computer computer can model this as reactive vals that recompute when project_id or pagination inputs change.

## Output files

- `lib/spotter_web/live/pane_list_live.ex` — Define `computer :session_data` block, remove `load_projects/1`, `append_session_page/3`, `do_append_session_page/4`, `pagination_keys/1` helpers, update template

## Technical specs

The challenge is that pagination state is per-project AND per-visibility (visible/hidden). ash_computer works best with a single set of inputs → vals. Two approaches:

**Approach A (recommended): Single computer that loads all project data**

Define a computer whose input is the full project list (from ProjectFilter), and whose val computes the enriched project data including sessions and pagination:

```elixir
computer :session_data do
  input :project_ids do
    initial []
    description "List of project IDs to load sessions for"
  end

  input :pagination_state do
    initial %{}
    description "Map of {project_id, visibility} => cursor for keyset pagination"
  end

  val :enriched_projects do
    description "Projects with visible/hidden sessions and pagination metadata"
    compute fn %{project_ids: project_ids, pagination_state: pagination_state} ->
      try do
        Enum.map(project_ids, fn project_id ->
          {visible, visible_meta} = load_project_sessions(project_id, :visible,
            after: Map.get(pagination_state, {project_id, :visible}))
          {hidden, hidden_meta} = load_project_sessions(project_id, :hidden,
            after: Map.get(pagination_state, {project_id, :hidden}))

          %{
            project_id: project_id,
            visible_sessions: visible,
            hidden_sessions: hidden,
            visible_has_more: visible_meta.has_more,
            visible_cursor: visible_meta.next_cursor,
            hidden_has_more: hidden_meta.has_more,
            hidden_cursor: hidden_meta.next_cursor
          }
        end)
      rescue
        _ -> []
      end
    end
  end

  event :load_more do
    handle fn %{pagination_state: state}, %{"project-id" => pid, "visibility" => vis} ->
      visibility = String.to_existing_atom(vis)
      # This needs to accumulate sessions, not replace them.
      # May need stateful approach or manual update_computer_inputs
      %{pagination_state: Map.put(state, {pid, visibility}, new_cursor)}
    end
  end
end
```

**Important consideration**: The load_more pattern requires appending sessions (not replacing). This may require:
- Using `stateful? true` to access previous vals
- Or using `update_computer_inputs/3` in a custom handle_event to accumulate sessions outside the computer
- Or tracking accumulated sessions in a separate assign alongside the computer

Evaluate which approach works cleanest during implementation. The key constraint is: existing sessions must be preserved when loading more.

## Source references

- `lib/spotter_web/live/pane_list_live.ex` lines 128-189 (load_projects, append_session_page, do_append_session_page, pagination_keys)
- `lib/spotter_web/live/pane_list_live.ex` lines 191-212 (load_project_sessions — this function stays, it's the underlying query builder)
- `lib/spotter_web/live/pane_list_live.ex` lines 65-73 (load_more_sessions handle_event)

## Edge cases

- **Accumulating sessions on load_more**: The current code appends new sessions (`Map.update!(keys.sessions, &(&1 ++ new_sessions))`). A computer val that recomputes from scratch won't accumulate. Need stateful approach or hybrid.
- **Initial load vs load_more**: On mount, all projects load their first page. On load_more, only one project's one visibility type gets appended.
- **Error handling**: Wrap Ash.read in try/rescue. Return [] for that project's sessions on error.
- **@sessions_per_page**: Keep the existing constant (20) for pagination limit.

## Architecture constraints

- Keep `load_project_sessions/3` as a regular private function (it builds the Ash query and calls Ash.read!)
- Template must still render per-project with visible/hidden sections
- PubSub sync_completed handler currently calls `load_projects(socket)` — need to update this to trigger computer recomputation instead (use `update_computer_inputs/3`)

## Definition of Done

- [ ] All requirements in the task description are implemented
- [ ] Pagination state no longer scattered across project map fields
- [ ] `pagination_keys/1` helper removed
- [ ] `append_session_page/3` and `do_append_session_page/4` removed or simplified
- [ ] Load More button works: appends sessions without losing existing ones
- [ ] Initial page load shows first 20 sessions per project per visibility
- [ ] Template updated to reference computer vals
- [ ] `mix compile` and `mix credo` pass

title: Define ToolCallStats computer for reactive stats loading
description:
Define a ToolCallStats computer inline in PaneListLive to reactively load tool call error counts when session IDs change.

## What and Why

Currently, tool call stats are loaded in a separate phase after sessions load (`load_tool_call_stats/1` called from `load_projects/1`, and `load_tool_call_stats_for/1` called from `do_append_session_page/4`). Stats are stored in a separate `tool_call_stats` assign as a map of session_id => %{total, failed}. When sessions change (initial load or load_more), stats must be manually reloaded or merged.

With ash_computer, stats become a reactive val that recomputes automatically when the session list changes, eliminating the need for manual stat loading orchestration.

## Output files

- `lib/spotter_web/live/pane_list_live.ex` — Define `computer :tool_call_stats` block, remove `load_tool_call_stats/1` and `load_tool_call_stats_for/1` helpers, update template

## Technical specs

```elixir
computer :tool_call_stats do
  input :session_ids do
    initial []
    description "List of session IDs to load tool call stats for"
  end

  val :stats do
    description "Map of session_id => %{total: int, failed: int}"
    compute fn %{session_ids: []} -> %{} end
  end

  val :stats do
    description "Map of session_id => %{total: int, failed: int}"
    compute fn %{session_ids: session_ids} ->
      try do
        Spotter.Transcripts.ToolCall
        |> Ash.Query.filter(session_id in ^session_ids)
        |> Ash.read\!()
        |> Enum.group_by(& &1.session_id)
        |> Map.new(fn {sid, calls} ->
          failed = Enum.count(calls, & &1.is_error)
          {sid, %{total: length(calls), failed: failed}}
        end)
      rescue
        _ -> %{}
      end
    end
  end
end
```

Note: Two val clauses with same name won't work in ash_computer. Use a single val with conditional logic:

```elixir
val :stats do
  compute fn %{session_ids: session_ids} ->
    if session_ids == [] do
      %{}
    else
      try do
        Spotter.Transcripts.ToolCall
        |> Ash.Query.filter(session_id in ^session_ids)
        |> Ash.read\!()
        |> Enum.group_by(& &1.session_id)
        |> Map.new(fn {sid, calls} ->
          failed = Enum.count(calls, & &1.is_error)
          {sid, %{total: length(calls), failed: failed}}
        end)
      rescue
        _ -> %{}
      end
    end
  end
end
```

After the session_data computer recomputes (from task spotter-65u.3), extract all session IDs and call `update_computer_inputs(socket, :tool_call_stats, %{session_ids: all_ids})` to trigger stats recomputation.

Template reference changes from `@tool_call_stats` to `@tool_call_stats_stats`.

## Component usage

- `require Ash.Query` — Already present in PaneListLive
- `Spotter.Transcripts.ToolCall` — Already aliased

## Source references

- `lib/spotter_web/live/pane_list_live.ex` lines 214-234 (load_tool_call_stats, load_tool_call_stats_for)
- `lib/spotter_web/live/pane_list_live.ex` lines 329-337, 406-414 (template stats display — both visible and hidden tables use same pattern)

## Edge cases

- **Empty session_ids**: Return empty map (no query needed)
- **Large session lists**: Current code loads all ToolCalls for all sessions and groups in memory. This is existing behavior — not changing it here, but worth noting as a future optimization (use Ash aggregates instead).

With reactive computer, stats recompute for all current session_ids at once, so no merge needed — but this means reloading stats for sessions we already had. Accept this trade-off for simplicity; optimize later if needed.

- Triggered by updating session_ids input from outside (after session_data computer updates)
- Template uses cond for display logic — keep same pattern, just change assign name

title: Transcript-Terminal Scroll Sync Spike
description:
## Problem

Spotter renders terminal output via xterm.js (tmux capture) and has parsed transcript data (Session/Message from JSONL). These are completely disconnected — there's no way to navigate between what's on screen in the terminal and which transcript message produced it.

## Solution

Build a pseudo-renderer that converts transcript messages into the same text Claude Code would render in the terminal. Then add a transcript panel beside the terminal and sync scroll positions by matching visible terminal text against pseudo-rendered output.

Approach: TDD — capture real transcript+terminal fixture pairs first, write tests, then implement.

## Acceptance Tests

- GIVEN a JSONL transcript and its corresponding terminal capture WHEN the pseudo-renderer processes the JSONL THEN each rendered line appears in the terminal capture
- GIVEN a pane view with a selected session WHEN the user scrolls the terminal THEN the transcript panel scrolls to the corresponding message
- GIVEN transcript messages of type tool_use WHEN rendered THEN they show with ● prefix matching Claude Code format

## Rabbit Holes

- Exact fidelity of pseudo-renderer to Claude Code's rendering — this is a spike, approximate is fine
- Subagent transcript rendering — out of scope
- Bidirectional sync (click transcript → scroll terminal) — out of scope

## No-gos

- No persistent pane↔session association (dropdown selection in memory only)
- No reverse scroll sync
- No subagent support
- No syntax highlighting in transcript panel

---
Appetite: supervised. Target: lib/spotter/services/, test/. Architecture: Ash/Phoenix/LiveView/xterm.js. Sources: lib/spotter_web/live/pane_view_live.ex, assets/js/app.js, lib/spotter/transcripts/message.ex, ~/.claude/projects/-home-marco-projects-spotter/*.jsonl.

title: Move LiveView event handlers out of async callback, remove legacy scroll fallback
description:
Debug toggle and scroll sync both rely on LiveView push_event data (breakpoint_map, debug_anchors). Plan:

2. Move scroll sync setup to mounted() synchronously using stored this._term reference
3. Remove the legacy scroll fallback (else branch in scroll handler that pushes terminal_scrolled)
4. Simplify _connectChannel to only contain Phoenix Channel concerns

6. Remove find_matching_message/2 and match_line_to_message/2 helper functions (lines 444-456)

title: Graphite UI Rework: Unified Dark Design System
description:
## Problem
Spotter's UI is built with inline styles scattered across 6 LiveView modules and a light-themed transcript panel CSS file. There is no design system: colors, spacing, typography, and component patterns are ad-hoc and inconsistent. The transcript panel uses a light theme (#f8fafc background) that clashes with the dark terminal and sidebar panels. The dashboard uses raw HTML tables with inline styles. Navigation is a minimal top bar with two links. Code syntax highlighting uses a GitHub-light theme that is unreadable against the dark surroundings. There is a dead /debug route. The result is a prototype that works but feels unpolished and hard to navigate.

## Solution
Implement the "Graphite" design system - a unified dark theme with layered surfaces, semantic accent colors, consistent typography (Bricolage Grotesque for UI, JetBrains Mono for code), and reusable CSS classes. Execute in 9 sequential tasks:
1. Design system foundation: CSS custom properties, base element styles, font loading, grain texture
2. Navigation & layout shell: sidebar nav replacing top bar, breadcrumbs
3. Dashboard redesign (PaneListLive): cards, filters, project grouping
4. Session review redesign (SessionLive): unified dark panels, tabbed sidebar
5. Subagent view redesign (SubagentLive): consistent with session view
6. Commit history redesign (HistoryLive): improved card layout and filters
7. Project review redesign (ProjectReviewLive): better annotation list
8. Remove debug terminal (DebugTerminalLive + /debug route)
9. Dark syntax highlighting theme replacing GitHub-light hljs styles

## Acceptance Tests
- GIVEN the design system foundation is applied WHEN any page loads THEN all surfaces use the Graphite palette (#0c0e14 through #2d3344), no inline color literals remain in HEEx templates, and Bricolage Grotesque renders for UI text
- GIVEN the sidebar navigation is implemented WHEN user is on any page THEN a compact left sidebar shows Dashboard and History links with the active page highlighted
- GIVEN the session review redesign is complete WHEN /sessions/:id loads THEN all three panels use dark backgrounds, transcript rows have semantic left-border accents, and the right sidebar has Commits/Annotations/Errors tabs
- GIVEN the debug terminal is removed WHEN user navigates to /debug THEN they receive a 404
- GIVEN the dark syntax highlighting is applied WHEN a code block renders THEN it uses light-on-dark colors readable against surface-1

## Rabbit Holes
- Over-engineering a component library: keep it to CSS classes and simple HEEx, not a full design system package
- Responsive/mobile: Spotter runs on localhost, just ensure nothing breaks at 1024px+
- CSS-in-JS or Tailwind migration: stay with plain CSS custom properties
- Accessibility audit: respect contrast ratios but do not scope a full WCAG audit

## No-gos
- Do not change any Elixir business logic, Ash resources, or data models
- Do not modify xterm.css (vendor file)
- Do not add new npm dependencies beyond the Google Fonts link
- Do not change the Phoenix channel/WebSocket terminal architecture
- Do not refactor JS hooks beyond theme config and highlight.js theme swap

---
Rig: spotter. Appetite: reviewed.
Target: priv/static/assets/spotter.css, lib/spotter_web/components/layouts/, lib/spotter_web/live/, lib/spotter_web/router.ex, assets/js/app.js.
Architecture: Phoenix LiveView + HEEx templates; CSS custom properties; esbuild for JS; no Tailwind.
Sources: priv/static/assets/spotter.css, lib/spotter_web/components/layouts/root.html.heex, lib/spotter_web/components/layouts/app.html.heex, lib/spotter_web/live/pane_list_live.ex, lib/spotter_web/live/session_live.ex, lib/spotter_web/live/subagent_live.ex, lib/spotter_web/live/history_live.ex, lib/spotter_web/live/project_review_live.ex, lib/spotter_web/live/debug_terminal_live.ex, lib/spotter_web/router.ex, assets/js/app.js.

title: Add GitHub Pages deployment workflow for Astro site
description:
Create GitHub Actions workflow to deploy the Astro site to GitHub Pages.

**Output files:**
- Create: `.github/workflows/deploy-pages.yml`

**Content requirements (verbatim YAML):**
```yaml
name: Deploy Astro site to Pages

on:
  push:
    branches:
      - main
    paths:
      - ".github/workflows/deploy-pages.yml"
      - "site/**"
  workflow_dispatch:

permissions:
  contents: read
  pages: write
  id-token: write

concurrency:
  group: pages
  cancel-in-progress: true

jobs:
  build:
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
    steps:
      - name: Checkout
        uses: actions/checkout@v4
      - name: Setup Node
        uses: actions/setup-node@v4
        with:
          node-version: 22
          cache: npm
          cache-dependency-path: site/package-lock.json
      - name: Install dependencies
        run: npm ci
        working-directory: site
      - name: Build Astro
        run: npm run build
        working-directory: site
      - name: Setup Pages
        uses: actions/configure-pages@v5
      - name: Upload artifact
        uses: actions/upload-pages-artifact@v3
        with:
          path: site/dist

  deploy:
    environment:
      name: github-pages
      url: ${{ steps.deployment.outputs.page_url }}
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
    needs: build
    steps:
      - name: Deploy to GitHub Pages
        id: deployment
        uses: actions/deploy-pages@v4
```

**Edge cases and constraints:**
- Workflow must not trigger for changes outside `site/**` and the workflow file.
- Keep concurrency group `pages` to prevent overlapping deploys.

**Source references:**
- `site/package-lock.json`
- <https://docs.github.com/en/pages/getting-started-with-github-pages/using-custom-workflows-with-github-pages>

title: Single-session transcript bootstrap sync + live tail updates
description:
## Goal
Implement reliable real-time session visibility and transcript freshness by syncing missing sessions individually on encounter, then keeping active sessions updated continuously with supervised GenServer tail workers.

## Why This Epic Is Necessary
Spotter currently misses transcript data for newly encountered sessions even though hooks are arriving, which causes `/sessions/:session_id` to show "No transcript available" for active work. Manual sync is too coarse and breaks the live UX expectation. We need a deterministic per-session bootstrap path plus continuous updates for active sessions.

## Target Area
- Hook ingress and session lifecycle:
  - `lib/spotter_web/router.ex`
  - `lib/spotter_web/controllers/session_hook_controller.ex`
  - `lib/spotter_web/controllers/hooks_controller.ex`
- Transcript ingest and persistence:
  - `lib/spotter/transcripts/jobs/sync_transcripts.ex`
  - `lib/spotter/transcripts/session.ex`
  - `lib/spotter/transcripts/message.ex`
  - `priv/repo/migrations`
- Runtime workers and orchestration:
  - `lib/spotter/services`
  - `lib/spotter/application.ex`
- Live UI updates:
  - `lib/spotter_web/live/pane_list_live.ex`
  - `lib/spotter_web/live/session_live.ex`
- Plugin hooks/scripts:
  - `spotter-plugin/hooks/hooks.json`
  - `spotter-plugin/scripts/*.sh`

## Architecture Constraints
- Do **not** call `SyncTranscripts.sync_all()` when discovering a missing session.
- Bootstrap sync must target only the encountered session/transcript.
- Ongoing freshness for active sessions must be owned by GenServer workers, not Oban jobs.
- Tail implementation must use `tail -F` behind a behavior adapter so the backend can be swapped to Elixir polling later without touching orchestration.
- Hook scripts must remain silent-fail and low-latency.
- LiveView should receive data via PubSub and update without manual refresh.

## Source References To Read Before Tasking
- `README.md` (hook performance contract)
- `lib/spotter_web/controllers/session_hook_controller.ex`
- `lib/spotter_web/controllers/hooks_controller.ex`
- `lib/spotter/transcripts/jobs/sync_transcripts.ex`
- `lib/spotter_web/live/pane_list_live.ex`
- `lib/spotter_web/live/session_live.ex`
- `spotter-plugin/hooks/hooks.json`
- `spotter-plugin/scripts/notify-session.sh`
- `spotter-plugin/scripts/tool-call-capture.sh`
- `spotter-plugin/scripts/post-tool-capture.sh`

## Success Criteria
- Encountering an unsynced session triggers **single-session** bootstrap ingest only.
- Active sessions are marked live in dashboard state.
- Transcript lines appear live in `SessionLive` while the session is active.
- No duplicate messages across repeated ingest cycles.
- Session end transitions status and stops tail workers cleanly.
close_reason: All 4 subtasks completed: lifecycle hooks + active session registry, bootstrap sync + incremental ingest, tail -F workers, and PubSub wiring into LiveViews.

title: Add lifecycle hooks and active session registry
description:
## Why This Task Is Necessary
Worker orchestration and live status rendering need authoritative session lifecycle signals. Without explicit start/end lifecycle state and a shared activity registry, we cannot reliably decide when to start/stop tail workers or what to show as active in the dashboard.

## Output Files
- `lib/spotter_web/router.ex`
- `lib/spotter_web/controllers/session_hook_controller.ex`
- `lib/spotter/services/active_session_registry.ex` (new)
- `lib/spotter/application.ex`
- `spotter-plugin/hooks/hooks.json`
- `spotter-plugin/scripts/notify-session-end.sh` (new)
- `test/spotter_web/controllers/session_hook_controller_test.exs` (new or expanded)
- `test/spotter/services/active_session_registry_test.exs` (new)

## Technical Specs
- Add endpoint: `POST /api/hooks/session-end`.
- Session end payload fields:
  - Required: `session_id`
  - Optional: `reason`, `transcript_path`, `cwd`
- Add `SessionEnd` entry to plugin hook config (`spotter-plugin/hooks/hooks.json`) calling `notify-session-end.sh`.
- `notify-session-end.sh` requirements:
  - Parse hook JSON from stdin.
  - POST to `/api/hooks/session-end`.
  - Silent-fail semantics, short curl timeouts, no stdout noise.
- Implement `Spotter.Services.ActiveSessionRegistry`:
  - OTP: `GenServer` with ETS table.
  - Activity model fields in ETS record: `session_id`, `pane_id`, `last_hook_at`, `ended_at`, `ended_reason`, `status`.
  - Status rule: ended if SessionEnd received; otherwise active when tmux pane exists OR `last_hook_at` is recent.
  - TTL: `90s`.
  - Sweep interval: `15_000ms`.
  - Public API:
    - `start_session(session_id, pane_id)`
    - `touch(session_id, source)`
    - `end_session(session_id, reason)`
    - `status(session_id)`
    - `status_map(session_ids)`
  - Broadcast topic: `session_activity`.
  - Broadcast payload keys: `session_id`, `status`, `last_activity_at`, `pane_present`, `ended_reason`.
- Wire service into supervision tree in `Spotter.Application`.
- Update existing session-start controller flow to call registry start/touch.
- Update hook controllers (`tool_call`, `file_snapshot`, `commit_event`) to call registry touch.

## Code Structure
- Keep session lifecycle endpoints in `SessionHookController`.
- Keep cross-cutting state in `ActiveSessionRegistry` service.
- Avoid embedding status logic in LiveViews.

## Edge Cases
- Duplicate SessionEnd requests are idempotent.
- SessionEnd for unknown session does not crash controller or registry.
- tmux unavailable returns `pane_present=false` without crashing sweeper.
- Missing optional payload fields are handled gracefully.

## Definition Of Done
- Session lifecycle hooks ingest successfully.
- Registry returns deterministic status for active/inactive/ended.
- `session_activity` PubSub events are emitted on transitions.
- Controller and registry tests cover happy path + idempotency + missing-field behavior.
close_reason: Implemented ActiveSessionRegistry GenServer, session-end hook endpoint, notify-session-end.sh script, hooks.json Stop event, wired touch calls into all hook controllers, and added comprehensive tests.

title: Implement single-session bootstrap sync and incremental ingest
description:
## Why This Task Is Necessary
The core bug is a missing transcript for a specific encountered session. Global sync is expensive and does not solve deterministic single-session catch-up timing. We need a targeted bootstrap path that ingests exactly that session and remains idempotent under repeated events.

## Output Files
- `lib/spotter/transcripts/jobs/sync_transcripts.ex`
- `lib/spotter/transcripts/session.ex`
- `lib/spotter/transcripts/message.ex`
- `priv/repo/migrations/<timestamp>_add_unique_index_messages_session_uuid.exs`
- `lib/spotter_web/controllers/hooks_controller.ex`
- `lib/spotter_web/controllers/session_hook_controller.ex`
- `lib/spotter_web/live/session_live.ex`
- `test/spotter/transcripts/jobs/sync_transcripts_test.exs`
- `test/spotter_web/controllers/hooks_controller_test.exs` (expanded)
- `test/spotter_web/live/session_live_test.exs` (expanded)

## Technical Specs
- Add targeted sync functions in `SyncTranscripts` (or extracted ingest service used by it):
  - `sync_session_by_id(session_id, opts \\ [])`
  - `sync_session_file(file_path, opts \\ [])`
- These functions must ingest only one transcript session and return structured result:
  - `%{session_id: ..., ingested_messages: n, ingested_tool_calls: n, status: :ok | :not_found | :error}`
- Bootstrap trigger points:
  - In hook flow when event arrives for unsynced session.
  - In `SessionLive.mount/3` when transcript is empty for that session.
- Explicit prohibition: no call to `sync_all()` from hook/session bootstrap paths.
- Incremental ingest rules:
  - Add unique DB index on `messages(session_id, uuid)`.
  - Add message upsert action in Ash (`:upsert`) and use it for batch ingest.
  - Repeated sync must not create duplicates.
- Session metadata updates:
  - Ensure `transcript_dir` is accepted in `Session` update action and written for existing rows.
- Unsynced predicate:
  - Session has no message rows OR `message_count` nil/0.

## Code Structure
- Keep existing `sync_all()` for manual bulk sync paths only.
- Bootstrap path should resolve single transcript file by session id + configured transcript directories.
- Keep file parsing behavior in existing parser module; do not duplicate parser logic.

## Edge Cases
- Missing transcript file returns `:not_found` result, not crash.
- Partial malformed JSON lines are skipped, valid lines still ingested.
- Session seen by hooks before JSONL exists should retry on subsequent encounters.
- `transcript_dir` nil from old stubs should be backfilled when file is found.

## Definition Of Done
- Encountering missing session ingests only that session.
- Running bootstrap repeatedly is idempotent.
- No duplicates in `messages` table.
- Existing session rows receive `transcript_dir` backfill.
- Tests cover no-sync-all guarantee, single-session ingest, and idempotency.
close_reason: Implemented sync_session_by_id/2, sync_session_file/2, Message upsert identity, transcript_dir backfill, bootstrap triggers in hook controller and SessionLive mount.

title: Implement transcript tail adapter behavior and tail -F workers
description:
## Why This Task Is Necessary
Bootstrap sync fixes initial missing data, but does not keep active transcripts fresh. We need long-lived per-session workers to stream updates while a session runs, without depending on manual refresh or global jobs.

## Output Files
- `lib/spotter/services/transcript_tail_adapter.ex` (new behavior)
- `lib/spotter/services/transcript_tail_adapter/tail_f.ex` (new)
- `lib/spotter/services/transcript_tail_worker.ex` (new)
- `lib/spotter/services/transcript_tail_supervisor.ex` (new)
- `lib/spotter/application.ex`
- `lib/spotter_web/controllers/hooks_controller.ex`
- `lib/spotter_web/controllers/session_hook_controller.ex`
- `scripts/tail_wrapper.sh` (new wrapper script)
- `test/spotter/services/transcript_tail_worker_test.exs` (new)
- `test/spotter/services/transcript_tail_adapter_tail_f_test.exs` (new)

## Technical Specs
- Do not use Oban for tail workers.
- Add behavior `Spotter.Services.TranscriptTailAdapter` with callbacks (example signatures):
  - `start(session_id, transcript_path, caller_pid, opts \\ []) :: {:ok, adapter_state} | {:error, term}`
  - `stop(adapter_state) :: :ok`
- Implement adapter `...TailF` using OS command `tail -F` via `Port.open`.
- Use wrapper script `scripts/tail_wrapper.sh` to execute `tail -F` and normalize shutdown behavior.
- Tail worker (`GenServer`) responsibilities:
  - Own adapter lifecycle.
  - Buffer incoming lines.
  - Debounce ingest trigger window: `500ms`.
  - Call single-session incremental sync (Task 2 API).
  - Publish updates to topic `session_transcripts:<session_id>`.
- Supervisor model:
  - `DynamicSupervisor` with one worker per session id.
  - Public API:
    - `ensure_worker(session_id, transcript_path)`
    - `stop_worker(session_id)`
- Worker start/stop policy:
  - Start when session is active and transcript path is known.
  - Stop on SessionEnd or inactive+stale from registry.

## Code Structure
- Behavior and implementation split is mandatory; worker must depend on behavior, not concrete tail implementation.
- Keep orchestration in worker/supervisor, not in controllers.

## Edge Cases
- Tail process exits unexpectedly: worker restarts adapter with backoff.
- Transcript file rotates or is recreated: `tail -F` should continue following by name.
- Worker receives events but ingest returns no new messages: do not spam PubSub.
- Duplicate worker ensure calls are idempotent.

## Definition Of Done
- Each active session has at most one worker.
- New transcript content results in PubSub update events.
- Session end/inactivity stops worker cleanly.
- Adapter can be swapped later without touching worker orchestration.
- Tests cover restarts, idempotent ensure, and publish behavior.
close_reason: Implemented TranscriptTailAdapter behavior, TailF implementation via Port, TranscriptTailWorker GenServer with debounced ingest, DynamicSupervisor with Registry, tail_wrapper.sh, wired session-end to stop workers.

title: Wire live activity/transcript PubSub into dashboard and session LiveViews
description:
## Why This Task Is Necessary
Even with backend sync and workers, users still won’t see live data unless LiveViews subscribe and react to events. This task closes the user-visible gap: dashboard activity badges and live transcript updates in session view.

## Output Files

  - Render session status badge values: `active`, `inactive`, `ended`.
  - Update only affected rows/assigns on incoming events.
- `SessionLive`:

  - On transcript update event, reload transcript-related assigns:
    - `messages`, `rendered_lines`, `errors`, `rework_events`, `commit_links`.

## Definition Of Done

- LiveView tests cover PubSub-driven updates for both pages.
