title: Use FakeTmux in all review-launch tests
description:
## Goal
Eliminate real tmux side effects from tests by ensuring every test path that launches a review session uses `Spotter.TestSupport.FakeTmux` instead of `Spotter.Services.Tmux`.

## Why this exists
A real test path still launches tmux in `ProjectReviewLive` tests, which leaves detached `spotter-review*` sessions behind and makes test behavior nondeterministic.

## Current evidence
- `test/spotter_web/live/project_review_live_test.exs` has an `open_conversation` test (`describe \"open_conversation\"`) that intentionally allows either success or failure depending on tmux availability.
- Running that single test creates a real tmux session (`spotter-review-project-*`).

## Output files
- `test/spotter_web/live/project_review_live_test.exs`
- `test/support/fake_tmux.ex`
- Any other `test/**/*_test.exs` files that trigger these launch paths:
  - `open_conversation`
  - `review_session`
  - direct `launch_project_review` / `launch_review_session`

## Technical spec
1. Standardize fake tmux setup in every affected test module.
- For each test module that can launch a review session, configure:
  - `Application.put_env(:spotter, :tmux_module, FakeTmux)`
  - `Application.delete_env(:spotter, :tmux_module)` in `on_exit`
  - `Application.delete_env(:spotter, :fake_tmux_launch_result)` in `on_exit`
  - `FakeTmux.start_link()` + `FakeTmux.stop()` lifecycle
- No test in `test/**/*_test.exs` should depend on local tmux availability.

2. Make `ProjectReviewLive` launch tests deterministic.
- Remove the nondeterministic assertion:
  - `assert html =~ \"review session\" or html =~ \"Failed to launch\"`
- Replace with fake-backed explicit success/failure tests using `:fake_tmux_launch_result`.

3. Ensure `FakeTmux` supports every launch API used by tests.
- Keep `launch_project_review/3`.
- Add `launch_review_session/2` if any test path needs it.
- Record calls so tests can assert launch invocation without touching tmux.

4. Hard requirement.
- After this task, there must be no direct test path that executes real `tmux new-session`.

## Source references
- `lib/spotter_web/live/project_review_live.ex`
- `lib/spotter_web/live/reviews_live.ex`
- `lib/spotter_web/live/pane_list_live.ex`
- `test/spotter_web/live/project_review_live_test.exs`
- `test/support/fake_tmux.ex`

## Acceptance checks
- `mix test test/spotter_web/live/project_review_live_test.exs` passes.
- `mix test` passes.
- Manual local verification while running the affected tests:
  - No new `spotter-review*` tmux sessions are created.

## Definition of done
- All review-launch tests run through `FakeTmux` only.
- Launch tests are deterministic and do not branch on tmux presence.
- No orphan `spotter-review*` sessions are left behind by test runs.

title: Unified transcript visualization and debug parity for session + subagent
description:
## Problem
`SessionLive` and `SubagentLive` currently duplicate transcript rendering logic and drift in capabilities. Only the main session view has debug affordances, tool results are silently truncated to 5 lines, and absolute paths are not consistently normalized across tool outputs (`Read`, `Glob`, `Grep`, `Bash`). This makes review/debugging slower and inconsistent between main-session and subagent transcripts.

## Solution
Create one shared transcript presentation pipeline and use it in both views:
- Shared LiveView-derived transcript data model (via `AshComputer.LiveView` where appropriate) so the same row metadata powers both pages.
- Shared transcript HEEx component that renders rows, debug sidecar, and expand/collapse controls with zero copy-paste between `SessionLive` and `SubagentLive`.
- Renderer metadata upgrades: per-row debug payload, tool-result grouping/line indexes, hidden-line counts, and code-language inference for read snippets.
- Debug mode shows pretty-printed full JSON payload per rendered row (side-by-side with rendered text) for both main and subagent transcripts.
- Tool results show first 10 lines by default with explicit expand control; no silent truncation.
- Path normalization converts absolute paths to project-relative paths across tool-use previews and tool-result lines.

## Acceptance Tests
- GIVEN the same fixture messages WHEN opening `/sessions/:session_id` and `/sessions/:session_id/agents/:agent_id` THEN transcript rows are rendered through the same shared component and expose the same debug/expand behaviors.
- GIVEN debug mode is enabled WHEN transcript rows render THEN each row shows pretty-printed JSON payload linked to that row, including message/type/tool metadata.
- GIVEN a tool result with more than 10 lines WHEN first rendered THEN only 10 lines are visible and a `Show N more lines` control is present; expanding reveals all remaining lines.
- GIVEN absolute paths in `Read`, `Glob`, `Grep`, and `Bash` inputs/results WHEN rendered THEN displayed paths are relative to the project directory.
- GIVEN line-numbered read output (`1→`, `2→`) WHEN rendered THEN rows are rendered as code and highlighted by highlight.js.

## Rabbit Holes
- Keeping separate transcript templates in sync instead of extracting a shared component.
- Implementing expand state in JavaScript only and losing state on LiveView rerender.
- Path normalization regexes that over-match and corrupt non-path text.

## No-gos
- Do not keep separate debug rendering code paths for session and subagent pages.
- Do not silently truncate tool-result output without an explicit expand affordance.
- Do not add a second syntax highlighting library; continue with highlight.js.

---
Rig: spotter. Appetite: reviewed.
Target: `lib/spotter/services`, `lib/spotter_web/live`, `lib/spotter_web/components`, `assets/js`, `priv/static/assets`, `test/spotter/services`, `test/spotter_web/live`, `assets/test`.
Architecture: Ash + Phoenix LiveView; use `AshComputer.LiveView` for shared transcript-derived UI state where needed; UI work must follow the AGENTS.md Frontend Tasks guidance (frontend design skill).
Sources: `lib/spotter/services/transcript_renderer.ex`, `lib/spotter_web/live/session_live.ex`, `lib/spotter_web/live/subagent_live.ex`, `lib/spotter_web/live/pane_list_live.ex`, `assets/js/app.js`, `priv/static/assets/spotter.css`, `test/spotter/services/transcript_renderer_test.exs`, `test/spotter_web/live/session_live_test.exs`, `assets/test/highlight-integration.test.js`, `https://hexdocs.pm/ash_computer/liveview-integration.html`.

description:

title: Upgrade TranscriptRenderer for relative paths, code snippets, and 10-line expandable groups
description:
## Why This Task Is Necessary
The current renderer drops tool-result lines after a hard cap of 5 and does not provide enough metadata for UI expansion/debug panels. It also only partially normalizes paths and does not reliably treat numbered read output as syntax-highlightable code. We need renderer output that is complete, structured, and shared by both session and subagent views.

## Output Files
- `lib/spotter/services/transcript_renderer.ex`
- `test/spotter/services/transcript_renderer_test.exs`
- `test/fixtures/transcripts/tool_heavy.jsonl` (only if additional fixture coverage is needed)

## Technical Specs
- Replace silent truncation behavior:
  - Remove hard data truncation for tool results.
  - Keep all tool-result lines in `render/2` output.
  - Introduce metadata for UI default folding:
    - `:tool_result_group` (stable group key; use `tool_use_id` when present)
    - `:result_line_index` (1-based index inside group)
    - `:result_total_lines` (total lines in group)
    - `:hidden_by_default` (`true` when `result_line_index > 10`)
  - Default visible budget must be exactly 10 lines per tool-result group.
- Path normalization:
  - Normalize absolute paths to project-relative paths in both tool-use previews and tool-result text.
  - Apply to outputs from `Read`, `Glob`, `Grep`, and `Bash` tool interactions.
  - Keep non-path text unchanged; do not mangle strings like `config/key`.
- Code snippet classification:
  - For line-numbered read output (`⎿ <number>→...`) mark rows as `render_mode: :code`.
  - Infer `code_language` from the associated `Read` file extension (e.g. `.ex/.exs -> elixir`, `.sh/.bash/.zsh -> bash`, `.json/.jsonl -> json`, fallback `plaintext`).
  - Preserve existing `render_mode: :plain` for non-code rows.
- Debug payload support:
  - Add `:debug_payload` map per rendered row containing enough raw context for sidecar rendering:
    - message identifiers (`id`/`uuid`), `type`, `role`
    - source block or source text fragment
    - `tool_use_id`/thread metadata
    - final rendered line text

## Component Usage
- Keep renderer API consumed by both `SessionLive` and `SubagentLive` via shared transcript computer/component.
- Preserve existing keys already used by CSS/LiveViews (`:kind`, `:tool_use_id`, `:thread_key`, `:subagent_ref`, `:code_language`, `:render_mode`, `:line_number`).

## Source References
- `lib/spotter/services/transcript_renderer.ex`
- `test/spotter/services/transcript_renderer_test.exs`
- `lib/spotter_web/live/session_live.ex` (current renderer consumer)
- `lib/spotter_web/live/subagent_live.ex` (current renderer consumer)

## Edge Cases
- Tool result without `tool_use_id` still gets deterministic group metadata.
- Empty tool result still renders `(empty)` with non-crashing metadata.
- Unknown/extensionless files in `Read` default to `plaintext` language.
- Paths outside `session_cwd` remain absolute.

## Architecture Constraints
- Renderer remains a pure data transform module (no LiveView/socket state).
- Do not introduce any frontend-only truncation assumptions in renderer output.
- Keep existing enriched-line shape backward-compatible while adding new keys.

## Definition Of Done
- `TranscriptRenderer.render/2` returns complete tool-result lines with 10-line default-visibility metadata.
- Read snippets are marked as code with inferred language and can be highlighted by existing highlight.js integration.
- Absolute-to-relative normalization works for Read/Glob/Grep/Bash examples.
- Renderer tests cover all new metadata and behavior.
close_reason: Removed silent 5-line truncation. All tool-result lines preserved with 10-line default-visibility metadata (tool_result_group, result_line_index, result_total_lines, hidden_by_default). Added debug_payload per row. Numbered read output in tool results marked as code with language inferred from Read file extension. 410 tests pass (13 new).

title: Persist relevant commits and file metrics in co-change compute
description:
## Goal
Extend the co-change compute pipeline to persist commit provenance per group and member file metrics (`size_bytes`, `loc`) at the group's `last_seen` commit.

## Output Files
- `lib/spotter/services/co_change_intersections.ex`
- `lib/spotter/services/co_change_calculator.ex`
- `lib/spotter/transcripts/jobs/compute_co_change.ex`
- `test/spotter/services/co_change_intersections_test.exs`
- `test/spotter/services/co_change_calculator_test.exs`
- `test/spotter/transcripts/jobs/compute_co_change_test.exs`

## Source References
- `lib/spotter/services/co_change_intersections.ex`
- `lib/spotter/services/co_change_calculator.ex`
- `lib/spotter/transcripts/jobs/compute_co_change.ex`
- `lib/spotter/transcripts/commit.ex`
- `lib/spotter/transcripts/co_change_group.ex`
- `lib/spotter/transcripts/co_change_group_commit.ex`
- `lib/spotter/transcripts/co_change_group_member_stat.ex`

## Implementation Spec
1. Extend `CoChangeIntersections.compute/2` output map to include `matching_commits` per group, where each item has `%{hash: String.t(), timestamp: DateTime.t()}` for commits containing all group members.
2. Keep existing group fields unchanged: `group_key`, `members`, `frequency_30d`, `last_seen_at`.
3. In `CoChangeCalculator.compute/2`, after group upsert:
- Upsert relevant rows in `co_change_group_commits` for each group's `matching_commits`.
- Delete stale rows in `co_change_group_commits` for that `project_id + scope + group_key` not present in current recomputation.
4. Persist member stats for each group member in `co_change_group_member_stats`:
- Determine `measured_commit_hash` as the commit corresponding to `last_seen_at` in `matching_commits`.
- Read file content at commit snapshot via git (`git show <hash>:<path>` equivalent in implementation).
- Compute `size_bytes` from byte size of snapshot content.
- Compute `loc` as count of non-empty lines after splitting on `\n`.
- Set `measured_at` from commit timestamp.
- Upsert and stale-delete member stats per group.
5. If commit hash from `matching_commits` is missing in `commits`, insert minimal commit row with available fields (`commit_hash`, `committed_at`, `git_branch` when available, `changed_files` when available).
6. Keep computation non-blocking and fail-safe:
- If one member snapshot cannot be read, log warning and continue remaining members/groups.
- If commit link persistence fails for one group, continue remaining groups while logging structured warning.
7. Add manual tracing spans/attributes around:
- group provenance persistence,
- member stat extraction,
- per-group error branch.
8. Keep all files included in computation; do not introduce ignore filtering.

## Acceptance Criteria
- Baseline pair `lib/spotter_web/live/pane_list_live.ex|lib/spotter_web/router.ex` remains frequency `11` for spotter project fixture/window.
- At least one `co_change_group_commits` row exists for that baseline group after compute.
- Two `co_change_group_member_stats` rows exist for the baseline group's two members, with non-null `size_bytes` and `loc` when snapshot exists.
- Repeated compute is idempotent (no duplicate commit/member rows).
- Tests cover partial snapshot-read failure without job failure.

description:
## Problem
Spotter tracks file snapshots and commits from Claude Code sessions but provides no way to see which files are most actively changing. Users must manually browse sessions to understand code churn patterns.

## Solution
Add a project-level file change heatmap:
1. Persist per-file change frequency and recency as an Ash resource
2. Compute heat scores from FileSnapshot data + git commit history (read directly from git on main branch, not the database) via an Oban job using a deterministic formula (frequency + recency decay)
3. Display a ranked heatmap in a new LiveView page

## Acceptance Tests

GIVEN a project with 10+ file snapshots across 5+ commits
WHEN the ComputeHeatmap job runs
THEN FileHeatmap rows are created for every unique non-binary file path with correct heat_score values

GIVEN a project with heatmap data
WHEN a user visits /projects/:project_id/heatmap
THEN files are displayed ranked by heat_score with frequency and recency data visible

GIVEN new file snapshots or commits are ingested
WHEN the hooks/sync pipeline completes
THEN a ComputeHeatmap job is enqueued for the project

## Rabbit Holes
- Do not include co-change analysis — that's a separate epic with its own algorithm.
- Do not attempt diff-level analysis. Work at file level only.
- Do not add AI scoring — separate epic.
- Do not add annotations — separate epic.

## No-gos
- No authentication (prototype on localhost).
- No Oban Pro features (project uses Oban.Engines.Lite).
- No backwards compatibility concerns (greenfield).

---
Rig: spotter. Appetite: reviewed.
Target: lib/spotter/transcripts/, lib/spotter/services/, lib/spotter/transcripts/jobs/, lib/spotter_web/live/, test/.
Architecture: Ash resources with AshSqlite, Oban worker (Lite engine), Phoenix LiveView. All computation in Oban jobs, never in LiveView render path.
Sources: lib/spotter/transcripts/file_snapshot.ex, lib/spotter/transcripts/session.ex (cwd for repo path), lib/spotter/transcripts/jobs/enrich_commits.ex (git CLI pattern), lib/spotter/transcripts.ex, lib/spotter_web/controllers/hooks_controller.ex, lib/spotter_web/live/pane_list_live.ex.
close_reason: All 3 acceptance tests met: FileHeatmap persistence (et3.6), ComputeHeatmap Oban job with git+snapshot data (et3.7), HeatmapLive visualization (et3.8). Full suite 248 tests pass. Remaining children (et3.1-5) belong to hotspot/AI-scoring/co-change epics per pitch rabbit holes.

title: Compute file heatmap and co-change graph from snapshots + commits
description:
Implement backend aggregation that turns file snapshots + commit links into a project heatmap and co-change graph.

Output files:
- `lib/spotter/services/file_hotspot_graph.ex` (new)
- `lib/spotter/transcripts/jobs/recompute_hotspots.ex` (new)
- `lib/spotter_web/controllers/hooks_controller.ex` (modify)
- `lib/spotter/transcripts/jobs/sync_transcripts.ex` (modify)
- `test/spotter/services/file_hotspot_graph_test.exs` (new)
- `test/spotter/transcripts/jobs/recompute_hotspots_test.exs` (new)
- `test/spotter_web/controllers/hooks_controller_test.exs` (modify)

Technical specs:
- Create `Spotter.Services.FileHotspotGraph.recompute(project_id, opts \\ [])` that:
  - reads `FileSnapshot` rows for sessions in project within rolling window (`window_days`, default `30`)
  - reads linked commits via `SessionCommitLink` and commit `changed_files`
  - updates `FileHeatmap` and `FileCochangeEdge`
- Co-change logic:
  - build file sets per commit from `Commit.changed_files`
  - create undirected pair edges for each pair in the same commit
  - canonicalize pair ordering (`left_path < right_path`)
  - increment `cochange_count_30d` and `last_cochanged_at`
- Heat score formula (deterministic and persisted):
  - `frequency_norm = min(:math.log1p(change_count_30d) / :math.log(21), 1.0)`
  - `cochange_norm = min(:math.log1p(cochange_degree_30d) / :math.log(11), 1.0)`
  - `recency_norm = :math.exp(-days_since_last_change / 14)`
  - `heat_score = Float.round((0.50 * frequency_norm + 0.35 * cochange_norm + 0.15 * recency_norm) * 100, 2)`
- Create Oban worker `Spotter.Transcripts.Jobs.RecomputeHotspots` that calls service above.
- Enqueue strategy:
  - after successful `file_snapshot` ingest in `HooksController`, enqueue recompute for that session’s project
  - after successful `commit_event` ingest, enqueue recompute for that session’s project
  - after each `sync_directory` batch in `SyncTranscripts`, enqueue recompute once per project
- Job uniqueness:
  - use Oban unique key by `project_id` with at least 30s period to coalesce bursts.

Source references:
- `lib/spotter_web/controllers/hooks_controller.ex`
- `lib/spotter/transcripts/file_snapshot.ex`
- `lib/spotter/transcripts/commit.ex`
- `lib/spotter/transcripts/session_commit_link.ex`
- `lib/spotter/transcripts/jobs/sync_transcripts.ex`

Edge cases:
- Commits with empty `changed_files` produce no edges.
- Projects with snapshots but no linked commits still get heatmap rows (cochange degree can be `0`).
- Deleted files remain rankable by `relative_path` if they were recently active.

Definition of Done:
- Recompute job can be triggered from hooks and sync pipeline without exceptions.
- Heatmap + co-change tables are fully populated for fixture data.
- Tests assert exact score math and pair canonicalization.

title: Compute file change heatmap via Oban job
description:
Implement the Oban worker that computes file change frequency and heat scores from FileSnapshot data + git commit history (read directly from git, not the database). Focus on the main branch only, not worktrees. All computation runs in the Oban job, never in LiveView.

## Output files
- lib/spotter/services/heatmap_calculator.ex (new)
- lib/spotter/services/git_log_reader.ex (new)
- lib/spotter/transcripts/jobs/compute_heatmap.ex (new)
- lib/spotter_web/controllers/hooks_controller.ex (modify)
- lib/spotter/transcripts/jobs/sync_transcripts.ex (modify)
- test/spotter/services/heatmap_calculator_test.exs (new)
- test/spotter/services/git_log_reader_test.exs (new)
- test/spotter/transcripts/jobs/compute_heatmap_test.exs (new)

## Technical specs

### HeatmapCalculator service
Create Spotter.Services.HeatmapCalculator with compute(project_id, opts) function.
Options: window_days (default 30), reference_date (default DateTime.utc_now() for deterministic tests).

Steps:
1. Load FileSnapshot rows for project sessions within rolling window.
2. Determine project git repo path from most recent session cwd.
3. Read commit history directly from git on main branch only (not worktree branches) via GitLogReader.
4. Build file frequency map from both snapshots and git commit changed files.
5. Track last_changed_at as most recent timestamp per file across both sources.
6. Compute heat score per file.
7. Upsert FileHeatmap rows. Delete stale rows outside window.

### GitLogReader service
Create Spotter.Services.GitLogReader — thin wrapper around git CLI.
Function: changed_files_by_commit(repo_path, opts) returns list of maps with hash, timestamp, files.
Options: since_days (default 30), branch (default main).

Shell out to: git -C repo_path log --name-only --format=COMMIT:%H:%ct --since=N days ago branch --no-merges
Parse output: split on COMMIT: markers, extract hash + unix timestamp + file list per commit.
Use --no-merges to skip merge commits (they inflate file counts).

Auto-detect branch: try git symbolic-ref refs/remotes/origin/HEAD, fall back to main, then master.

### Binary file filtering
Skip files matching binary extensions: .png .jpg .jpeg .gif .bmp .ico .svg .webp .woff .woff2 .ttf .eot .otf .pdf .zip .tar .gz .bz2 .7z .exe .dll .so .dylib .o .beam .ez .pyc .class .jar

### Heat score formula (frequency + recency only, no co-change)
days_since = max(DateTime.diff(reference_date, last_changed_at, :second) / 86_400, 0)
frequency_norm = min(:math.log1p(change_count_30d) / :math.log(21), 1.0)
recency_norm = :math.exp(-days_since / 14)
heat_score = Float.round((0.65 * frequency_norm + 0.35 * recency_norm) * 100, 2)

### Oban worker
Spotter.Transcripts.Jobs.ComputeHeatmap:
use Oban.Worker, queue: :default, max_attempts: 3, unique: [keys: [:project_id], period: 30]

### Enqueue triggers
- HooksController.file_snapshot/2: after snapshot creation, enqueue for session project.
- HooksController.commit_event/2: after commit ingestion, enqueue for session project.
- SyncTranscripts: after processing directory, enqueue once per project.

## Source references
- lib/spotter_web/controllers/hooks_controller.ex — ingestion endpoints
- lib/spotter/transcripts/file_snapshot.ex — relative_path, timestamp
- lib/spotter/transcripts/session.ex — cwd field for repo path resolution
- lib/spotter/transcripts/jobs/enrich_commits.ex — existing git CLI pattern
- lib/spotter/transcripts/jobs/sync_transcripts.ex — sync trigger point

## Edge cases
- Project with no sessions (no cwd): skip git log, heatmap from snapshots only. Log warning.
- Git repo not accessible: git commands fail gracefully, heatmap from snapshots only.
- Main branch detection failure: fall back to main, then master, then skip git log.
- Merge commits excluded via --no-merges.
- Score staleness: heat_score updates only when job runs, not daily.
- Deleted files: rankable if recently active in window.

## Definition of Done
- ComputeHeatmap triggers from hooks and sync pipeline without exceptions.
- GitLogReader tests cover: parsing git log output, empty repos, branch detection.
- HeatmapCalculator tests assert: exact score math, binary filtering, stale cleanup, snapshot-only projects, combined data.
close_reason: Implemented GitLogReader, HeatmapCalculator, ComputeHeatmap job with enqueue triggers in HooksController and SyncTranscripts. All 18 new tests pass, full suite green (242 tests), credo clean.

title: Improve Session Transcript Readability and Structure in SessionLive
description:
## Problem
The session transcript panel is hard to scan because it uses dense dark styling, full absolute file paths, and flat line-by-line rendering that separates tool calls from their outputs. Thinking content is not visually distinct, code is plain text, and subagent references are easy to miss and not interactive.

## Solution
Upgrade transcript rendering and presentation in `SessionLive` only:
- emit richer renderer metadata so UI can classify rows, thread tool outputs, detect code blocks, and detect subagent references,
- shorten file paths to session-relative paths,
- render code blocks with `highlight.js`,
- style thinking rows in gray muted blocks,
- switch transcript panel from black-heavy theme to readable light surface with explicit contrast tokens,
- make subagent references prominent and clickable with placeholder event behavior,
- group tool result lines inline under the corresponding tool call (threaded visual block).

## Acceptance Tests
- GIVEN a transcript containing absolute file paths WHEN it renders in SessionLive THEN tool call/result previews show session-relative paths.
- GIVEN a transcript containing fenced code or numbered code output WHEN it renders THEN code rows are syntax highlighted with `highlight.js` and remain readable without JS.
- GIVEN thinking blocks WHEN rendered THEN they appear in muted gray style distinct from normal assistant text.
- GIVEN tool call + tool result pairs WHEN rendered THEN results are visually grouped inline under their originating tool call.
- GIVEN transcript rows referencing subagents WHEN clicked THEN a placeholder LiveView event is emitted and the clicked row receives visible focus/active treatment.
- GIVEN the updated theme WHEN evaluated for normal body text THEN foreground/background combinations meet WCAG 2.2 AA contrast targets.

## Rabbit Holes
- Overfitting heuristics for code and subagent detection across many transcript variants.
- Over-abstracting style system before stabilizing SessionLive UX.
- Building full subagent navigation now (explicitly deferred).

## No-gos
- No new route/page for subagent transcripts in this epic.
- No scope expansion to `PaneViewLive`.
- No database schema migration.

---
Rig: spotter. Appetite: reviewed. Target: `lib/spotter/services/`, `lib/spotter_web/live/`, `assets/js/`, `lib/spotter_web/components/layouts/`. Architecture: Phoenix LiveView + Ash resources + existing esbuild pipeline. Sources: `lib/spotter/services/transcript_renderer.ex`, `lib/spotter_web/live/session_live.ex`, `assets/js/app.js`, `lib/spotter_web/components/layouts/root.html.heex`, https://www.w3.org/TR/WCAG22/#contrast-minimum, https://www.w3.org/WAI/ARIA/apg/patterns/disclosure/, https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTML/Element/pre, https://highlightjs.org/.

  - `session`: session struct
  - `project`: project struct
  - `link_types`: unique list of atom link types for this `(commit_id, session_id)` pair
  - `max_confidence`: highest confidence across links for this pair
- Deduplicate by `(commit_id, session_id)`; do not duplicate rows when multiple link records exist.
- Include all linked sessions for the selected commit (multiple sessions per commit required).
- Exclude commits that have zero linked sessions after filtering.

title: Fix project review tmux session cleanup with heartbeat + TTL parity
description:
## Goal
Ensure all review tmux sessions are automatically cleaned up via heartbeat + TTL, including both `spotter-review-<short-id>` and `spotter-review-project-<short-id>` sessions, so stale review sessions do not accumulate in `tmux list-sessions`.

## Investigation Summary
- On Thursday, February 12, 2026, `tmux list-sessions` shows many stale `spotter-review-project-*` sessions created between Wednesday, February 11, 2026 22:32 and Thursday, February 12, 2026 00:18.
- Existing cleanup task `spotter-tw7` only implemented lifecycle wiring for per-session review (`spotter-review-*`) from `SessionLive`.
- `SessionLive` currently does `register -> periodic heartbeat every 10s -> deregister on terminate`.
- `ProjectReviewLive` currently launches project review tmux sessions but never registers them in `ReviewSessionRegistry` and never sends heartbeats.
- Result: project review sessions never enter ETS registry, so TTL sweep never evaluates/kills them.

## Target Area
- `lib/spotter_web/live/project_review_live.ex`
- `lib/spotter/services/review_session_registry.ex`
- `lib/spotter/services/tmux.ex` (only if interface/testability updates are needed)
- `test/spotter_web/live/project_review_live_test.exs`
- `test/spotter/services/review_session_registry_test.exs`

## Architecture Constraints
- Keep cleanup lifecycle centralized in `Spotter.Services.ReviewSessionRegistry`.
- Keep heartbeat interval at `10_000` ms and registry TTL at `30` seconds unless changed intentionally with matching tests and docs.
- Keep registry key as tmux session name (no new DB table, no migration).
- Preserve existing `SessionLive` cleanup behavior for `spotter-review-*` sessions.
- Avoid blocking UI events with tmux cleanup calls.

## Source References
- `lib/spotter_web/live/project_review_live.ex`
- `lib/spotter_web/live/session_live.ex`
- `lib/spotter/services/review_session_registry.ex`
- `lib/spotter/services/tmux.ex`
- `test/spotter_web/live/project_review_live_test.exs`
- `spotter-tw7`

title: Wire ProjectReviewLive into ReviewSessionRegistry heartbeat lifecycle
description:

## Technical specs
1. Add `ReviewSessionRegistry` to module aliases in `ProjectReviewLive`.

4. In `handle_event("open_conversation", ...)` success path (`{:ok, name}`):
   - If `socket.assigns.review_session_name` is set and different from `name`, call `ReviewSessionRegistry.deregister(previous_name)` before replacing it.

   - Schedule heartbeat timer: `Process.send_after(self(), :review_heartbeat, @review_heartbeat_interval)`.

- Rapid repeated clicks on "Open conversation" should not leak old tracked names; previous tracked session must be deregistered before tracking the new one.

title: Track and Display Tool Call Outcomes
description:
## Problem
Claude Code sessions execute hundreds of tool calls (Read, Write, Edit, Bash, Grep, etc.), and some fail. Currently, there's no way to see aggregate failure rates per session or jump to specific errors in the transcript. The plugin only captures file changes for Write/Edit/Bash, missing success/failure outcomes for all other tools. When reviewing a session, it's hard to identify which tool calls failed and diagnose session problems.

## Solution
1. Add a PostToolUse hook (`.*`) for successful tool calls and a PostToolUseFailure hook (`.*`) for failed ones. Each calls a capture script that POSTs to a new endpoint. Keep existing file-capture hooks unchanged.
2. Create a ToolCall Ash resource storing: session_id, tool_use_id, tool_name, is_error, error_content. Link to transcript via tool_use_id (Message already has this field — no line numbers needed).
3. During transcript sync, extract tool_result messages and upsert ToolCall records, catching any missed by the plugin.
4. Display aggregate tool call stats (total, failed) per session in the dashboard table.
5. In session view, add an Errors section listing failed tool calls. Click jumps to the matching Message in the transcript (found via tool_use_id).

## Acceptance Tests
- GIVEN a session with 50 tool calls (5 failures) WHEN PostToolUse and PostToolUseFailure hooks fire THEN 50 ToolCall records created with correct is_error flags
- GIVEN a synced transcript WHEN sync runs THEN ToolCall records created for all tool_result messages
- GIVEN dashboard with sessions WHEN page loads THEN each row shows X calls (Y failed)
- GIVEN session view with 3 failed tool calls WHEN Errors section loads THEN 3 error entries shown with tool names and error snippets
- GIVEN user clicks error entry WHEN clicked THEN transcript panel scrolls to the matching message and highlights it
- GIVEN plugin POST fails WHEN hook executes THEN hook exits 0 and doesnt block Claude

## Rabbit Holes
- Parsing complex tool_result content structures (stick to simple is_error boolean + first 500 chars of error text)
- Handling duplicate tool calls from plugin vs sync (upsert on tool_use_id)

## No-gos
- No retry logic for tool calls
- No filtering by tool type in UI (show all errors)
- No real-time updates (sync + plugin hooks only)
- No authentication/authorization

title: tmux waiting overlay summaries for Claude
description:
## Problem
Claude sessions can sit waiting for user input in tmux panes and become easy to miss when multiple panes/sessions are active. Spotter currently captures session/tool metadata, but it does not surface "you need to respond" state in-context on the active pane, and it does not provide a quick summary of what happened before the pause.

## Solution
Add a Claude Notification-driven waiting detector in the Spotter plugin, then show a pane-local tmux popup after 5 minutes of waiting. The popup must target the exact pane that emitted the waiting signal and be dismissable by any key. The popup content is a concise summary generated server-side with AshAi using a configurable Haiku model.

The implementation must keep hook scripts non-blocking: hook scripts only schedule/cancel lightweight background work, while transcript reading and LLM summarization happen in Spotter server code.

## Acceptance Tests
- GIVEN Claude emits a waiting/idle notification for a pane WHEN 300 seconds pass without cancellation THEN a popup is shown on that exact pane.
- GIVEN the popup is shown WHEN any key is pressed THEN the popup closes immediately.
- GIVEN a popup is shown THEN popup width equals pane width and popup height equals configured overlay height (default 16).
- GIVEN summary generation is requested THEN input is built from conversation start and end within configurable budget (default 4000 token-equivalent chars) and returned as compact text.
- GIVEN summarization fails (parse error/model error/timeout) THEN a deterministic fallback summary is returned and popup still renders.

## Rabbit Holes
- Overfitting waiting detection to fragile string parsing in notification payloads.
- Blocking hook path with expensive shell/HTTP calls.
- Race conditions from repeated notifications for the same pane/session.
- Popups appearing on wrong pane/client due to target misuse.

## No-gos
- Do not add Codex support in this epic.
- Do not run heavy transcript parsing/LLM calls inside hook execution path.
- Do not introduce backward-compat fallback layers beyond current greenfield architecture.

- Fallback summary rules (deterministic, no LLM):
  - Include session id short form.
  - Include approximate message/tool counts from parsed window.
  - Include last user-facing action when available.

title: Terminal scrollback — show full session history in xterm.js
description:
## Problem
When viewing a Claude Code session in Spotter's xterm.js terminal, users can only see the last ~24 lines (the current tmux viewport). The full session history is lost because `tmux capture-pane` is called without scrollback flags, and xterm.js only accumulates content streamed after connection.

## Solution
1. Use `tmux capture-pane -S -` to capture the full scrollback buffer (not just the visible viewport) on initial load
2. Increase xterm.js `scrollback` option to handle large histories (e.g. 10,000 lines)

## Acceptance Tests
- GIVEN a tmux pane with 500+ lines of history WHEN a user opens the pane in Spotter THEN they can scroll up to see all prior output
- GIVEN a tmux pane with ANSI color codes in history WHEN scrollback is captured THEN colors render correctly in xterm.js

## Rabbit Holes
- Very large scrollback buffers (100k+ lines) could cause slow initial load or high memory usage. Start with tmux's default history-limit and revisit if needed.
- Tmux control mode streaming may re-send content that overlaps with the initial capture. Minor visual duplication is acceptable for now.

## No-gos
- Not implementing infinite scroll / lazy loading of history
- Not persisting terminal history to a database
- Not adding search functionality (separate feature)

---

title: Subagent Transcript Viewing
description:
## Problem
Spotter indexes subagent metadata (agent_id, slug, message_count) during transcript sync but discards the actual messages from subagent JSONL files. Users cannot view what a subagent did, and subagents are invisible on the dashboard. For sessions with significant subagent work (often 50%+ of a session's output), this is a major gap in review capability.

## Data Model
`Message` gains a nullable `belongs_to :subagent` FK. Parent session messages have `subagent_id: nil`; subagent messages have `subagent_id` set to the Subagent record's PK. SessionLive filters with `is_nil(subagent_id)` to exclude subagent internal conversations. SubagentLive queries by `subagent_id` FK. The existing string `agent_id` attribute stays for backward compatibility.

`Annotation` gains an optional `belongs_to :subagent` FK so annotations can be scoped to a specific subagent transcript (separate from session-level annotations).

## Solution
1. Add `belongs_to :subagent` (nullable FK) on Message. Migrate the messages table.
2. Import subagent JSONL messages during sync, setting `subagent_id` to the Subagent record.
3. Update SessionLive to filter `is_nil(subagent_id)` when loading messages.
4. Add optional `subagent_id` FK to Annotation for scoped annotations.
5. Show expandable subagent rows beneath each session in the dashboard.
6. Add SubagentLive page at `/sessions/:session_id/agents/:agent_id` with two-panel layout (transcript + annotations), reusing `TranscriptRenderer` and `TranscriptSelection` JS hook.

## Acceptance Tests
- GIVEN a session with subagent JSONL files WHEN sync runs THEN subagent messages are persisted in `messages` table with `subagent_id` FK set and `session_id` set to parent session.
- GIVEN a synced session with subagent messages WHEN SessionLive loads THEN only parent-session messages appear in the transcript (subagent messages excluded).
- GIVEN a session with subagents WHEN dashboard loads THEN subagent rows appear beneath the session row (expandable), showing slug, message count, and a link.
- GIVEN a subagent link WHEN user clicks THEN SubagentLive loads with rendered transcript.
- GIVEN SubagentLive transcript WHEN user selects text THEN annotation creation form appears.
- GIVEN a saved subagent annotation WHEN user clicks it THEN the referenced transcript messages are highlighted.
- GIVEN existing session sync WHEN subagent messages already exist THEN re-sync skips re-import (idempotent).

## Rabbit Holes
- Do not add xterm.js terminal to SubagentLive (subagents have no tmux pane).
- Do not add subagent-to-subagent navigation or nesting.
- Do not modify the existing SessionLive terminal annotation workflow.

## No-gos
- No subagent live terminal connections.
- No changes to commit linking for subagents.
- No subagent filtering/search on the dashboard.

---

title: Add subagent FK to Message and import subagent messages during sync
description:
Add a nullable belongs_to :subagent FK on the Message resource and import subagent JSONL messages during transcript sync. Update SessionLive to exclude subagent messages from the parent session transcript.

**Context**: Currently sync_subagent_file/2 parses subagent JSONL files but only stores metadata. Subagent messages are discarded. Without a proper FK, importing them would pollute the parent session's transcript view. Adding subagent_id FK on Message cleanly separates parent vs subagent messages.

2. In Subagent resource (lib/spotter/transcripts/subagent.ex):

   Add create_subagent_messages!/3 following the same pattern as existing create_messages!/2 (lines 181-216):

     existing =
       Message
       |> Ash.Query.filter(subagent_id == ^subagent.id)
       |> Ash.read!()
       |> length()

       Logger.debug("Skipping existing messages for subagent")
     else
       messages
       |> Enum.filter(& &1[:timestamp])
       |> Enum.map(fn msg ->

           message_id: msg[:message_id],
           type: msg[:type],

       end)
       |> Enum.chunk_every(@batch_size)
       |> Enum.each(fn batch ->
         Ash.bulk_create!(batch, Message, :create, return_errors?: true)
       end)
     end
   end

     case JsonlParser.parse_subagent_file(file) do

         subagent = upsert_subagent!(session, parsed)
         create_subagent_messages!(session, subagent, parsed.messages)
       {:error, reason} ->

   end

5. In SessionLive (lib/spotter_web/live/session_live.ex):

title: Track File Changes During Claude Code Sessions
description:
## Problem
When reviewing Claude Code sessions in Spotter, we can see the transcript messages but lack visibility into how files evolved during the session. There's no way to answer "what did file X look like after step 3 but before step 7?" Bash commands that modify files (migrations, scaffolds, installs) are opaque — we see the command but not what files changed.

## Solution
Extend the spotter plugin (from spotter-y5l.1) with PreToolUse and PostToolUse hooks that capture file state and POST snapshots to a new Spotter endpoint. Store snapshots in a FileSnapshot Ash resource.

**Write/Edit tools**: PreToolUse reads current file from disk (before state). PostToolUse reads new file from disk (after state). Both keyed by tool_use_id.

**Bash tool**: PreToolUse captures git baseline (git status --porcelain + git diff --name-only). PostToolUse diffs against baseline, reads content of newly changed files, POSTs snapshots.

**Data model**: FileSnapshot with session_id (FK), tool_use_id, file_path, relative_path, content_before, content_after, change_type (:created/:modified/:deleted), source (:write/:edit/:bash), timestamp.

## Acceptance Tests
- GIVEN Claude uses Write to create new file WHEN hooks fire THEN FileSnapshot created with content_before=nil, content_after=file content, change_type=:created, source=:write
- GIVEN Claude uses Edit on existing file WHEN hooks fire THEN FileSnapshot created with both content_before and content_after, change_type=:modified, source=:edit
- GIVEN Claude runs mix ash.migrate via Bash WHEN PostToolUse fires THEN FileSnapshots created for newly created migration files with source=:bash
- GIVEN Spotter server is down WHEN hooks fire THEN scripts exit silently without blocking Claude
- GIVEN 5 FileSnapshots for same session WHEN queried via JSON API THEN returns all 5 ordered by timestamp
- GIVEN FileSnapshot with tool_use_id abc WHEN correlated THEN matches Message with same tool_use_id

## Rabbit Holes
- Large file content: no size limit for now, add truncation later if needed
- Binary files: skip in hook scripts (check with file command or extension)
- Race conditions from async POSTs: use timestamp for ordering
- Bash baseline temp files: use /tmp/spotter-baseline-TOOL_USE_ID.txt, cleanup after POST

## No-gos
- No filesystem watching (inotify) — only capture on tool use
- No retroactive scanning of existing transcripts
- No diff UI in this epic — just store the data
- No content compression/deduplication

title: Create Phoenix endpoint for receiving file snapshots
description:
Add a Phoenix controller endpoint that receives POST requests from the spotter plugin hooks with file snapshot data.

**Output files:**
- Create: lib/spotter_web/controllers/hooks_controller.ex
- Modify: lib/spotter_web/router.ex (add API pipeline + route)

**Technical specs:**

Controller: SpotterWeb.HooksController with action file_snapshot/2.

Route: POST /api/hooks/file-snapshot under a new :api pipeline (plug :accepts, ["json"]). Add to router.ex:

pipeline :api do
  plug :accepts, ["json"]
end

scope "/api", SpotterWeb do
  pipe_through :api
  post "/hooks/file-snapshot", HooksController, :file_snapshot
end

Controller logic:
1. Find session by params["session_id"] — look up Spotter.Transcripts.Session by the session_id UUID field (not the primary key). Use Ash.Query.filter(session_id == ^session_id_str) |> Ash.read_one().
2. Build snapshot params from request body: tool_use_id, file_path, relative_path, content_before, content_after, change_type (String.to_existing_atom), source (String.to_existing_atom), timestamp (DateTime.from_iso8601).
3. Create FileSnapshot via Ash.create(FileSnapshot, params).
4. Return 201 on success, 404 if session not found, 422 on validation error, 400 on bad request.
5. Must handle missing session gracefully — hooks fire before transcript sync may have imported the session. If session not found, return 404 (hook script ignores errors via || true).

**Source references:**
- lib/spotter_web/router.ex — existing router structure (currently only :browser pipeline)
- lib/spotter/transcripts/session.ex — session_id field is the Claude UUID, not the PK

**Edge cases:**
- change_type/source must be valid atoms — use String.to_existing_atom to prevent atom table pollution
- timestamp parsing: fall back to DateTime.utc_now() if invalid
- content_before/content_after can be null — don't require them

**Definition of Done:**

- [ ] Controller created with proper error handling
- [ ] Route added with :api pipeline
- [ ] ExUnit tests in test/spotter_web/controllers/hooks_controller_test.exs: valid POST -> 201, unknown session -> 404, missing fields -> 400, invalid atoms -> 400

description:
Create PreToolUse and PostToolUse shell scripts that capture file state during Claude Code sessions and POST snapshots to Spotter. Update hooks.json to register these hooks.

- Create: spotter-plugin/scripts/pre-tool-capture.sh
- Create: spotter-plugin/scripts/post-tool-capture.sh

**hooks.json additions:**
Add to existing hooks object:
PreToolUse: [{matcher: "Write|Edit|Bash", hooks: [{type: "command", command: "${CLAUDE_PLUGIN_ROOT}/scripts/pre-tool-capture.sh", timeout: 5000}]}]
PostToolUse: [{matcher: "Write|Edit|Bash", hooks: [{type: "command", command: "${CLAUDE_PLUGIN_ROOT}/scripts/post-tool-capture.sh", timeout: 10000}]}]

**pre-tool-capture.sh** — reads JSON from stdin, captures before state:
- For Write/Edit: extract tool_input.file_path via jq. If file exists, read content and save to /tmp/spotter-before-TOOL_USE_ID.json (jq -Rs escaped). If file doesn't exist, save null.
- For Bash: run git diff --name-only HEAD + git status --porcelain | awk '{print $2}', sort | uniq, save to /tmp/spotter-git-baseline-TOOL_USE_ID.txt. Handle non-git repos (create empty baseline).
- Must set -euo pipefail but exit 0 always (never block Claude).

**post-tool-capture.sh** — reads JSON from stdin, captures after state and POSTs:
- For Write/Edit: read content_before from temp file, read current file content as content_after. Determine change_type (created if before was null, modified otherwise, deleted if file gone). Compute relative_path via git rev-parse --show-toplevel. POST to ${SPOTTER_URL:-http://localhost:1100}/api/hooks/file-snapshot. Cleanup temp file.
- For Bash: capture current git state same as PreToolUse. Use comm -13 baseline current to find newly changed files. For each: read content, check git show HEAD:path for before content (if tracked). POST snapshot for each file. Cleanup temp files.
- All curl calls must have || true to fail silently.
- Uses jq for JSON construction (jq -n --arg ...).

**Environment:** SPOTTER_URL env var, defaults to http://localhost:1100 (dev server port from config).

**Dependencies:** Requires jq and curl on PATH. Scripts use #\!/usr/bin/env bash.

- spotter-plugin/hooks.json — existing structure from spotter-y5l.1
- spotter-plugin/scripts/notify-session.sh — existing hook script pattern
- Claude Code hooks docs: hooks receive JSON on stdin with tool_name, tool_input, session_id, tool_use_id

**Edge cases:**
- Binary files: check with file --mime-type before reading; skip if not text/*
- Symlinks: resolve with readlink -f before reading
- Large files: skip if > 1MB (wc -c)
- Non-git repos: Bash baseline creates empty file, no files detected as changed

title: Fix terminal showing content from all tmux panes
description:
## Problem
When visiting `/sessions/<id>`, the xterm.js terminal displays mixed content from ALL panes in the tmux session, not just the target pane. This includes beam.smp logs, shell output, and other Claude sessions. It creates a recursive feedback loop where Phoenix debug logs about `terminal_scrolled` events appear in the terminal, triggering more scroll events with increasingly nested escaped content.

Root cause: `terminal_channel.ex:88` ignores the `target_pane` field in tmux control mode `%output` lines. When `tmux -C attach-session -t %2655 -r` runs, control mode emits `%output %<pane_id> <data>` for ALL panes in the attached session — the channel forwards everything without filtering.

Secondary issue: grouped tmux sessions (e.g. `2572` + `2572-2660`) cause `tmux list-panes -a` to return each pane twice, producing duplicate entries in the pane list UI.

## Solution
1. Filter tmux control mode output by pane_id — only forward `%output` lines matching the target pane
2. Deduplicate `list_panes` results by pane_id to handle grouped tmux sessions

## Acceptance Tests
- GIVEN a session view is open for a pane in a multi-pane tmux session WHEN other panes produce output THEN only the target pane's output appears in xterm.js
- GIVEN grouped tmux sessions exist WHEN the pane list is loaded THEN each pane appears only once

## Rabbit Holes
- Stale SessionRegistry entries (pane_id mapped to old session_id) — out of scope for this fix, tracked separately if needed

## No-gos
- No changes to SessionRegistry lookup logic
- No changes to transcript loading

---
Rig: spotter. Appetite: automated. Target: lib/spotter_web/channels, lib/spotter/services. Architecture: Phoenix Channel + tmux control mode. Sources: lib/spotter_web/channels/terminal_channel.ex, lib/spotter/services/tmux.ex.
close_reason: Both subtasks complete: pane filtering and deduplication

title: Filter tmux control mode output by pane_id
description:
The terminal channel forwards `%output` from ALL panes in the tmux session because `terminal_channel.ex:88` uses `_target_pane` (underscore-prefixed, ignored). Only output matching the target pane should be forwarded to xterm.js.

**Output files**: `lib/spotter_web/channels/terminal_channel.ex`

**Technical specs**: In `handle_info({port, {:data, data}}, %{assigns: %{port: port}} = socket)` (line 80), bind `socket.assigns.pane_id` to a variable before the `Enum.each` loop, then use Elixir's pin operator (`^`) to match only output from the target pane:

```elixir
target_pane = socket.assigns.pane_id

Enum.each(lines, fn line ->
  case parse_control_line(line) do
    {:output, ^target_pane, content} ->
      push(socket, "output", %{data: decode_output(content)})
    _ ->
      :ok
  end
end)
```

**Source references**: `lib/spotter_web/channels/terminal_channel.ex` (lines 59-97 for the streaming handler, lines 156-164 for `parse_control_line/1`)

**Edge cases**: The pane_id format in `%output` lines (e.g. `%2655`) must match `socket.assigns.pane_id` exactly. Both use tmux's native `%N` format — no conversion needed. The debug mode handler (line 75) is unaffected since it has a separate pattern match on `mode: :debug`.

**Architecture constraints**: Phoenix Channel, Port-based tmux control mode streaming.

**Definition of Done**:
- All requirements in the task description are implemented
- Visiting a session page in a multi-pane tmux session shows only the target pane's output
- No recursive feedback loop from Phoenix debug logs appearing in the terminal
close_reason: Pin-matched target_pane in control mode output handler to filter by pane_id

title: Deduplicate list_panes for grouped tmux sessions
description:
Grouped tmux sessions (e.g. `2572` and `2572-2660` sharing the same windows/panes) cause `tmux list-panes -a` to return each pane multiple times — once per session group member. This produces duplicate entries in all downstream consumers including the pane list UI.

**Output files**: `lib/spotter/services/tmux.ex`

**Technical specs**: Add `|> Enum.uniq_by(& &1.pane_id)` to the pipeline in `list_panes/0` (line 20-23), after `Enum.map(&parse_pane_line/1)`:

```elixir
panes =
  output
  |> String.split("\n", trim: true)
  |> Enum.map(&parse_pane_line/1)
  |> Enum.uniq_by(& &1.pane_id)
```

`Enum.uniq_by` keeps the first occurrence per pane_id, which is the primary tmux session (listed first by tmux).

**Source references**: `lib/spotter/services/tmux.ex` (lines 14-32 for `list_panes/0`). Downstream consumers: `list_claude_panes/0` (line 37), `lib/spotter_web/live/pane_list_live.ex`, `lib/spotter_web/live/session_live.ex` (`pane_dimensions/1`, `find_review_pane/1`).

**Architecture constraints**: All consumers call `list_panes/0` — deduplicating at the source fixes all of them.

**Definition of Done**:
- All requirements in the task description are implemented
- With grouped tmux sessions active, `Tmux.list_panes()` returns each pane_id exactly once
close_reason: Added Enum.uniq_by to deduplicate panes from grouped tmux sessions

title: Code Snippet Annotations
description:
## Goal
Deliver production-ready AI hotspot scoring as a dependable input for code-snippet annotations by making hotspot/co-change views discoverable, ensuring scoring is triggered at the correct pipeline boundary, enforcing required LLM credentials at boot, and adding observability for the hotspot pipeline.

## Architecture Constraints
- Stack: Ash + Phoenix LiveView + Oban + OpenTelemetry.
- Keep existing project-scoped routes working while adding global entry points.
- Job orchestration must be deterministic: hotspot scoring is triggered only after heatmap computation completes.

title: Enqueue ScoreHotspots from ComputeHeatmap and harden cwd resolution
description:
## Goal
Ensure hotspot scoring runs at the correct pipeline boundary (after heatmap compute) and does not skip scoring just because the newest session cwd is missing.

## Output Files
- `lib/spotter/transcripts/jobs/compute_heatmap.ex`

- `test/spotter/transcripts/jobs/score_hotspots_test.exs` (new)

## Source References
- `lib/spotter/transcripts/jobs/compute_heatmap.ex`
- `lib/spotter/transcripts/jobs/score_hotspots.ex`
- `lib/spotter/transcripts/jobs/sync_transcripts.ex`
- `lib/spotter_web/controllers/hooks_controller.ex`

## Implementation Specification
1. In `ComputeHeatmap.perform/1`:
- After `HeatmapCalculator.compute(project_id)` completes successfully, enqueue `ScoreHotspots` with `%{project_id: project_id}`.
- Do not enqueue from hooks/sync fanout sites; `ComputeHeatmap` is the single enqueue boundary for hotspot scoring.
- If enqueue fails, log warning and keep worker fail-safe (do not crash the whole pipeline).

2. In `ScoreHotspots.resolve_repo_path/1`:
- Replace current "latest session only" logic with fallback search:
  - query recent sessions for project with non-nil `cwd`, sorted desc by `inserted_at`.
  - pick first `cwd` where `File.dir?/1` is true.
  - if none found, return `:skip`.
- Add clear logs showing skip reason and number of checked candidates.

3. Keep fanout consistency:
- `hooks_controller` and `sync_transcripts` continue enqueuing `ComputeHeatmap` and `ComputeCoChange` only.
- No direct enqueue of `ScoreHotspots` in those modules.

## Edge Cases
- Project has heatmap rows but all session cwd paths are stale/missing.
- Duplicate enqueue attempts from frequent ingest events should remain safe via worker uniqueness.

## Acceptance Criteria
- Running `ComputeHeatmap` enqueues `ScoreHotspots`.
- Scoring proceeds when at least one valid cwd exists, even if newest cwd is missing.
- No direct hotspot enqueue in hook/sync fanout code.
- Tests validate enqueue boundary and cwd fallback behavior.

title: Improve Dashboard Session Labels and Resume Metadata
description:
## Goal
Improve dashboard session discoverability by showing the same human-friendly name/description metadata that `claude --resume` uses, and fix unreliable session start timestamps.

## Problem
The dashboard currently shows mostly technical fields (short session id, branch, message count, tool count). `Started` is unreliable for sessions whose transcript begins with a `file-history-snapshot` record that has no timestamp. Meanwhile Claude already has better resume metadata (`customTitle`, `summary`, `firstPrompt`) in `~/.claude/projects/*/sessions-index.json`, but Spotter does not ingest or display it.

## Solution
1. Ingest resume metadata from `sessions-index.json` during transcript sync and persist it on `sessions` rows.
2. Make session start/end timestamp extraction robust by using first/last non-nil message timestamp with safe fallbacks.
3. Update dashboard rendering so session name/description are human-friendly and `Started` is deterministic and readable.
4. Add regression tests for metadata parsing, fallback precedence, and timestamp reliability.

## Acceptance Tests
- GIVEN a transcript directory with `sessions-index.json` entries WHEN sync runs THEN matching `sessions` rows store `custom_title`, `summary`, and `first_prompt`.
- GIVEN a session whose first JSONL line has no timestamp WHEN parsed THEN `started_at` equals the first non-nil message timestamp.
- GIVEN directories without `sessions-index.json` WHEN sync runs THEN sync completes without errors and existing fallback labels still render.
- GIVEN `custom_title` exists WHEN dashboard renders THEN session label uses `custom_title` instead of slug/id.

title: Track Session Rework From Transcript and Surface It in UI
description:
## Problem
Spotter currently surfaces tool-call stats and failures, but it does not identify when the same file is edited again later in the same session. That repeated write/edit activity is a strong rework signal (often caused by linter/test feedback) and is currently invisible in both the session detail and dashboard.

## Solution
Add transcript-derived rework tracking as a first-class persisted record:
1. Define a `SessionRework` Ash resource for each repeated file modification event (second+ successful modification of the same file in one session).
2. During transcript sync, compute rework via a running aggregate over parsed messages (Write/Edit tool_use + matching successful tool_result), then bulk upsert rework records.
3. In session detail, render a Rework panel that lists identified rework entries and supports click-to-jump into the transcript.
4. In dashboard, show per-session rework count.

## Acceptance Tests
- GIVEN a transcript where `lib/foo.ex` is modified 3 times successfully in one session WHEN sync runs THEN 2 `SessionRework` records exist for that file (occurrence indexes 2 and 3)
- GIVEN a failed/rejected Write/Edit tool_result WHEN sync runs THEN no rework record is produced for that failed attempt
- GIVEN a session with rework entries WHEN Session detail renders THEN Rework panel shows file path + occurrence count and each item is clickable
- GIVEN user clicks a rework item WHEN click event fires THEN transcript scrolls to the matching tool_use line and row highlight is applied briefly
- GIVEN dashboard session rows WHEN page renders THEN each row shows rework count derived from persisted `SessionRework` records
- GIVEN sync is re-run for same transcript WHEN upsert executes THEN rework records are not duplicated

## Rabbit Holes
- Tool payload shape differences (`content` map vs list, missing tool_use_id, partial tool results) can break naive extraction
- File path normalization across absolute paths, cwd-relative paths, and missing cwd can over/under-count rework
- Jump behavior currently relies on JS hooks; event wiring must be explicit and resilient when terminal connection is delayed

## No-gos
- No retrospective inference from git commits or file snapshots for this feature (derive from transcript parse only)
- No cross-session or cross-project rework aggregation in this epic
- No scoring/weighting of rework severity beyond integer count and occurrence index

---

title: Compute SessionRework via running aggregate during transcript sync
description:
Compute rework during transcript parsing using an explicit running aggregate, then persist the derived records during sync. Rework is defined as the 2nd+ successful `Write`/`Edit` modification to the same file within a single session.

Output files:
- `lib/spotter/transcripts/jsonl_parser.ex` (running aggregate extractor)
- `lib/spotter/transcripts/jobs/sync_transcripts.ex` (persist session rework records)
- `test/spotter/transcripts/jsonl_parser_test.exs` (aggregator behavior coverage)
- `test/spotter/transcripts/jobs/sync_transcripts_test.exs` (new sync persistence coverage)

Technical specs:
- Add a parser-facing extractor, e.g. `JsonlParser.extract_session_rework_records(messages, opts \\ [])`, and run it in a single pass over transcript order.
- Use explicit intermediate aggregate models (maps/structs; names must appear in code and tests):
  - `pending_file_tools`: `%{tool_use_id => %{tool_use_id, tool_name, file_path, relative_path, timestamp, message_uuid}}`
  - `file_mod_counts`: `%{file_key => non_neg_integer}`
  - `first_tool_use_by_file`: `%{file_key => tool_use_id}`
  - `rework_records`: `[%{tool_use_id, file_path, relative_path, occurrence_index, first_tool_use_id, event_timestamp, detection_source}]`
- Extraction rules:
  1. From assistant messages, collect `tool_use` blocks with `name in ["Write", "Edit"]` and `input.file_path`.
  2. Match corresponding user `tool_result` block via `tool_use_id`.
  3. Count only successful results (`is_error != true`).
  4. Increment `file_mod_counts[file_key]`; if count >= 2, append record with that `occurrence_index` and stable `first_tool_use_id` from first successful modification.
  5. Remove matched `tool_use_id` from `pending_file_tools` after processing to prevent duplicate counting.
- File key normalization:
  - Prefer project-relative path when `session_cwd` is provided and `file_path` is under that cwd.
  - Otherwise use original absolute path.
  - Persist both `file_path` and `relative_path` (when derivable).
- In `SyncTranscripts`, add `create_session_reworks!/2` that:
  - Calls parser extractor with `parsed.messages` and `session.cwd`.
  - Injects `session_id` into each record.
  - Bulk upserts in chunks with action `:upsert` on `Spotter.Transcripts.SessionRework`.
- Wire sync call in `sync_session_file/4` after messages are created and before subagent sync.
- Keep behavior idempotent across repeated sync runs.

Source references:
- `lib/spotter/transcripts/jsonl_parser.ex` (message normalization and parse flow)
- `lib/spotter/transcripts/jobs/sync_transcripts.ex` (`create_messages!/2` and `create_tool_calls!/2` bulk patterns)
- `lib/spotter/services/transcript_renderer.ex` (`to_relative_path/2` normalization behavior)
- `test/fixtures/transcripts/subagent.jsonl` (real `Write` tool_use shape)

Edge cases:
- Ignore missing `tool_use_id`, missing `file_path`, malformed blocks, or unmatched results.
- Ignore failed/rejected Write/Edit attempts (`is_error: true`) so they do not inflate rework.
- Preserve deterministic ordering for emitted records by transcript order.

Architecture constraints:
- Parsing must remain stream-friendly and linear-time over message count.
- Do not depend on plugin file-snapshot hooks for this feature; derive strictly from transcript message content.

title: Close review tmux sessions with registry + heartbeat + TTL
description:
Review tmux sessions (spotter-review-*) launched via Tmux.launch_review_session/1 are never cleaned up. They accumulate until manually killed. Add a registry with heartbeat/TTL so sessions are automatically killed when no longer being viewed.

## Approach

Create a new Spotter.Services.ReviewSessionRegistry GenServer that:
1. Tracks active review tmux sessions with a last-heartbeat timestamp
2. Accepts heartbeats from LiveView processes viewing the review
3. Runs a periodic sweep (every 15s) that kills tmux sessions whose last heartbeat exceeds the TTL (30s)

The SessionLive LiveView sends a heartbeat on mount and via a periodic :send_heartbeat timer (every 10s). On terminate/2, it explicitly deregisters. The TTL sweep handles cases where terminate never fires (browser crash, network drop).

## Output files
- lib/spotter/services/review_session_registry.ex — new GenServer with ETS table
- lib/spotter/services/tmux.ex — add kill_session/1 function
- lib/spotter_web/live/session_live.ex — register, heartbeat, deregister
- lib/spotter/application.ex — add to supervision tree

## Definition of Done
- ReviewSessionRegistry GenServer exists with register/heartbeat/deregister/sweep
- Tmux.kill_session/1 exists
- SessionLive sends heartbeats for review sessions and deregisters on terminate
- Review tmux sessions are killed within ~30s of navigating away
- No errors when tmux session is already gone
- ReviewSessionRegistry is in the supervision tree
close_reason: Implemented ReviewSessionRegistry with heartbeat/TTL sweep, Tmux.kill_session/1, and SessionLive integration

title: Add Project Filter Chips to Dashboard
description:
## Problem
The dashboard loads ALL projects expanded in one long scrollable list (pane_list_live.ex lines 186-310). With 5+ projects, it's cluttered. No way to focus on one project's sessions without scrolling past others.

## Solution
1. Add clickable project filter chips at top of Session Transcripts section. One chip per project with session count.
2. "All" chip selected by default (selected_project_id = nil).
3. Clicking a chip updates assigns, template filters projects list.
4. Selected chip highlighted blue (#1a6b3c), unselected gray (#333).

## Acceptance Tests
- GIVEN 3 projects WHEN page loads THEN All chip selected, all projects shown
- GIVEN All selected WHEN click ProjectA chip THEN only ProjectA sessions shown
- GIVEN ProjectA selected WHEN click All THEN all projects shown again
- GIVEN filter applied WHEN Sync runs THEN filter preserved
- GIVEN no projects WHEN page loads THEN no chips shown

## Rabbit Holes
- URL param persistence — defer
- Chip sorting/grouping — defer, render in query order

## No-gos
- No URL persistence (resets on reload)
- No search/autocomplete for projects
- No schema changes

title: Emit ingest run progress events from transcript sync jobs
description:
Add ingest run tracking payloads and fine-grained sync progress events so LiveViews can show actual ingestion progress while Oban jobs are running.

**Output files:**
- `lib/spotter/transcripts/jobs/sync_transcripts.ex`
- `test/spotter/transcripts/jobs/sync_transcripts_test.exs`

**Technical specs:**
1. `SyncTranscripts.sync_all/0`:
- Generate `run_id` (`Ash.UUID.generate()` or equivalent UUID string).
- Read config once, compute `projects_total`, and include `run_id` in every enqueued project job args.
- Broadcast once before enqueue loop:
  - Topic: `"sync:progress"`
  - Message: `{:ingest_enqueued, %{run_id: run_id, projects_total: projects_total, projects: [project_name, ...]}}`
- Return `{:ok, %{run_id: run_id, projects_total: projects_total}}`.

2. `perform/1` project lifecycle broadcasts:
- On start, broadcast:
  - `{:sync_started, %{run_id: run_id, project: name, dirs_total: integer, sessions_total: integer}}`
- While processing sessions/files, broadcast incremental updates after each processed session file:
  - `{:sync_progress, %{run_id: run_id, project: name, dirs_done: integer, dirs_total: integer, sessions_done: integer, sessions_total: integer}}`
- Keep completion/error broadcasts, but include `run_id` on both payloads.

3. Progress accounting:
- `sessions_total` = total count of session JSONL files selected for sync after applying `@max_sessions_per_sync` cap per directory.
- `dirs_total` = number of matching directories.
- `dirs_done` increments when a directory finishes.
- For zero-work runs (`dirs_total == 0` or `sessions_total == 0`), still emit `sync_started` then `sync_completed` with zero counts.

4. Maintain existing behavior:
- Keep `@max_sessions_per_sync` cap.
- Keep heatmap enqueue on successful project sync.
- Keep error broadcast and re-raise behavior.

**Source references:**
- `lib/spotter/transcripts/jobs/sync_transcripts.ex`
- `lib/spotter/transcripts/jobs/compute_heatmap.ex`
- `lib/spotter_web/live/pane_list_live.ex` (current progress consumer)

**Edge cases:**
- Invalid regex/config read failures should still produce `sync_error` payload with `run_id` when `perform/1` starts.
- Progress broadcast must not crash sync if PubSub delivery fails.

**Definition of Done:**
- Backend emits enqueue/start/progress/completed/error events with `run_id` and concrete counters.
- `SyncTranscripts.sync_all/0` has deterministic return shape used by UI.
- New test file `test/spotter/transcripts/jobs/sync_transcripts_test.exs` verifies event payload shape and counter progression for at least one successful run and one empty run.

title: Fix orphaned spotter-review tmux session cleanup
description:
## Goal
Ensure `spotter-review-*` tmux sessions are cleaned up after inactivity even when the original LiveView process is gone (tab closed, app restarted, or worktree server stopped).

## Investigation Evidence (2026-02-12)
- `tmux list-sessions` showed 12 detached `spotter-review*` sessions still running `claude`.
- Tidewave runtime checks showed:
  - `Process.whereis(Spotter.Services.ReviewSessionRegistry)` was alive.
  - `:ets.tab2list(:review_session_registry)` was `[]`.
  - LiveView channel count was `0`.
  - `SpotterWeb.TerminalChannel` process count was `0`.
- This proves sessions can remain as **orphans** even when no active web/socket connections exist.

## Root Cause Hypothesis
`ReviewSessionRegistry` only sweeps names present in its ETS table. That table is in-memory and lost on node restart. Existing tmux sessions are not reconciled from tmux itself, so orphaned review sessions survive indefinitely.

## Output Files
- `lib/spotter/services/tmux.ex`
- `lib/spotter/services/review_session_registry.ex`
- `lib/spotter_web/live/pane_list_live.ex`
- `test/spotter/services/review_session_registry_test.exs`
- `test/spotter_web/live/pane_list_live_test.exs` (create if missing)

## Implementation Spec
1. Add tmux session introspection in `Spotter.Services.Tmux`.
- Add `list_sessions/0` that returns all tmux sessions with at least:
  - `session_name`
  - `session_created`
  - `session_activity`
  - `session_attached`
- Add `list_review_sessions/0` that filters names with prefix `spotter-review-`.

2. Extend `ReviewSessionRegistry` sweep to reconcile orphans.
- Keep existing ETS stale-heartbeat eviction behavior.
- During each `:sweep`, also inspect `Tmux.list_review_sessions/0`.
- For each review session from tmux:
  - If ETS has fresh heartbeat (`now - heartbeat <= @ttl`), keep it.
  - If ETS is missing and tmux activity is older than `@ttl`, kill session.
  - If ETS heartbeat is stale, kill session and delete ETS row.
- Never crash registry if tmux query fails; continue and reschedule sweep.

3. Remove launch race in `PaneListLive` review flow.
- Replace fire-and-forget `Task.start(fn -> Tmux.launch_review_session(...) end)` with direct launch handling.
- On `{:ok, _name}`, keep current navigation behavior.
- On `{:error, reason}`, stay on page and flash error.

4. Logging/observability.
- When a sweep kills a session, emit a log with session name and reason (`stale_heartbeat` or `orphan_inactive`).

## Test Requirements
1. `ReviewSessionRegistry` tests:
- Orphan review session (not in ETS) with old tmux activity gets killed.
- Orphan review session with recent activity is retained.
- Stale ETS row + existing tmux session gets killed and ETS entry removed.
- Tmux failure during sweep does not crash the GenServer.

2. `PaneListLive` tests:
- Review launch success path still navigates to `/sessions/:session_id`.
- Review launch failure path sets flash and does not navigate.

## Definition of Done
- Reproduce cleanup behavior manually:
  - Start review session, disconnect UI, wait >30s, verify `spotter-review*` tmux session is gone.
  - Restart Spotter while review sessions exist; wait one sweep cycle and verify old inactive review sessions are removed.
- `mix test` passes.
- `mix credo --strict` passes.

- GIVEN a hidden session WHEN user clicks "Unhide" THEN session reappears in main list
- GIVEN multiple projects with hidden sessions THEN each project shows its own collapsed "Hidden sessions" section with correct count
- GIVEN page reload THEN hidden/visible state persists

- Auto-clearing hidden sessions after N days (defer)
- Keyboard shortcuts (defer)

## No-gos

- Do NOT use transient state — must persist to DB

title: Link Annotations to Claude Code Session IDs
description:
## Problem
Annotations are tied to ephemeral tmux pane_id values like "%16". When a pane dies or tmux restarts, annotations become orphaned. We can't correlate annotations with Claude Code sessions or transcripts.

## Solution
Use a **Claude Code plugin** to notify Spotter of {session_id, pane_id} mappings. The plugin uses a `hooks.json` to declare a SessionStart hook that reads session_id from stdin JSON and $TMUX_PANE from environment, then POSTs to a Phoenix endpoint. Annotations switch from pane_id to session_id as their key.

Components:
1. Plugin directory (`spotter-plugin/`) with `hooks.json` + `scripts/notify-session.sh` — POSTs session_id + pane_id to Spotter
2. Phoenix endpoint (/api/hooks/session-start) — receives and stores the mapping
3. Schema migration — annotations: replace pane_id with session_id
4. PaneViewLive — resolve session_id via stored mapping, use for annotation CRUD
5. scripts/setup_worktree.sh — add `--plugin-dir` flag to claude command (no per-worktree hook copying)

### Plugin Structure
```
spotter-plugin/
├── hooks.json          # Declares SessionStart hook
└── scripts/
    └── notify-session.sh  # POSTs session_id + pane_id to Spotter
```

### Why plugin over bare hooks?
- Single directory, shared by all worktrees via `--plugin-dir` CLI flag
- Multiple lifecycle events in one `hooks.json` (extensible for Stop, PostToolUse, etc.)
- ${CLAUDE_PLUGIN_ROOT} for portable script paths
- No per-worktree file copying needed

## Acceptance Tests
- GIVEN Claude Code starts in a tmux pane WHEN SessionStart hook fires THEN Spotter receives session_id + pane_id mapping
- GIVEN a stored mapping WHEN PaneViewLive mounts for that pane THEN it resolves the session_id
- GIVEN annotation created with session_id WHEN pane dies and restarts with same session (resume) THEN annotation still loads
- GIVEN a new worktree WHEN setup_worktree.sh runs THEN claude command includes --plugin-dir flag

## Rabbit Holes
- Hook script must be async (non-blocking) to not slow Claude startup
- Server might not be running when hook fires — script should fail silently
- Session resume vs new session — both fire SessionStart, mapping should upsert
- Pane ID stability: tmux pane IDs are stable for the pane lifetime but change on pane recreation. The SessionStart hook fires on every start AND resume, so mapping self-heals.

## No-gos
- No PID/file heuristics for session detection (plugin solves this cleanly)
- No migration of existing pane_id annotations (clean slate)
- No error-tracking hooks yet (future work)

---

title: Migrate annotation schema from pane_id to session_id
description:
Replace pane_id with session_id in the Annotation resource and add bidirectional Ash relationships.

**What and why:** Annotations must reference sessions instead of panes so they persist across tmux restarts and can be viewed alongside transcript data.

**Output files:**

- lib/spotter/transcripts/annotation.ex (modify)
- lib/spotter/transcripts/session.ex (modify)

**Technical specs:**

Migration (SQLite can't drop columns, so recreate table):
```elixir
execute("CREATE TABLE annotations_v2 (
  id TEXT PRIMARY KEY,
  session_id TEXT NOT NULL REFERENCES sessions(id),
  selected_text TEXT NOT NULL,
  start_row INTEGER NOT NULL,
  start_col INTEGER NOT NULL,
  end_row INTEGER NOT NULL,
  end_col INTEGER NOT NULL,
  comment TEXT NOT NULL,
  inserted_at TEXT NOT NULL,
  updated_at TEXT NOT NULL
)")
execute("DROP TABLE annotations")
execute("ALTER TABLE annotations_v2 RENAME TO annotations")
execute("CREATE INDEX annotations_session_id_index ON annotations(session_id)")
```

Annotation resource changes in lib/spotter/transcripts/annotation.ex:
- Remove: attribute :pane_id, :string, allow_nil?: false
- Add: attribute :session_id, :uuid, allow_nil?: false
